This could be seen as an indication that the communist conception of Europe did have an impact on the Eastern European people.}}</ref>

column1: In 2019, a [[Pew Research Center]] survey found that between 58 and 65 percent of Eastern Europeans felt positively about [[living standards]], education and [[national pride]] in the post-Communist era.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=30 years after communism, eastern Europe divided on democracy's impact
column8: quote=Asked how they felt their countries had advanced, central and eastern Europeans were most positive about education (65%), living standards (61%) and national pride (58%). They were less happy about law and order (44%) and family values (41%), and a majority (53%) said healthcare had got worse in the post-communist era.}}</ref> In the same year, it was reported that the group were living close to ten years longer on avergage, since 1990, with longevity recorded as much as 10 percent higher for some.<ref name=\"goldenage2019\">{{Cite news
column10: title='This is the golden age': eastern Europe's extraordinary 30-year revival
column15: quote=Since then, longevity has surged as much as 10% in some parts of the region, and east Europeans are now more likely to be nearer 80 than 70 when they die.}}</ref>

column1: In 2020, it was reported how the [[European Union]]'s policy of free movement had enabled or encouraged millions of Eastern Europeans to return home from Germany, and other large European economies, after job losses created by the [[coronavirus pandemic]].<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=After coronavirus: how will Europe rebuild?
column8: quote=If Germany’s success in handling the pandemic is partly down to an army of migrant doctors and nurses, it should not be to the detriment of central and eastern Europe. Free movement of labour has also, paradoxically, led to the return home of millions of eastern Europeans.}}</ref>

column1: A 2013 study at [[Bucharest University]] proposed how a culture where Eastern European people seem under interrogation, for all political and cultural decisions taken by them, has developed due to the cultural conflict caused by public transition from communism to democracy.<ref>{{cite study
column5: title=Political Attitudes and Mentalities. Eastern European Political Culture: Modeling Studies
column9: quote=he long transition processes from the communist to democratic regimes made almost all Eastern European people and their countries experience during the past two decades the need to explain their choices, values, beliefs, norms, attitudes, symbols, grievances or prejudices, their institutions, regimes, and discourses.}}</ref>

column1: In a 2018 [[Feminist Media Studies]] journal piece, [[University of Vienna]] Research Fellow Katharina Wiedlack criticized Western cultural perceptions, which she argued can frame Eastern Europeans as unthinking, unoriginal or possessing lower morality.<ref>{{cite book
column3: title=In/visibly different: Melania Trump and the othering of Eastern European women in US culture
column8: quote=The view on Eastern European people as unable to produce original thinking, and accordingly stealing from their Western peers, does not only confirm their questionable morals and character, it also confirms the superiority of Western (here US) thinking, culture, and being.}}</ref> A 2019 [[Roskilde University]] study was critical of discriminatory Danish media representations of Eastern European people, which it described as portraying them as a racially inferior working-class, prone to criminality, who's 'otherness' was to be subsumed by integration into a \"Danish '[[whiteness studies
column13: title=The Representation of Eastern Europeans in Danish Media
column17: quote=They are presented as an ‘inferior race’ consisting of ‘cheap labor’ and criminals, who ‘invade’ Denmark and cause economical and security problems for Danish population. The notions ‘Us”’ (Danish people) and ‘Them’ (Eastern Europeans) are common in Eastern European discourse in Danish media. The integration of Eastern Europeans is considered as converting them to Danish ‘whiteness’}}</ref>

column1: Large numbers of Eastern Europeans have emigrated from the region between the 18th and 21st centuries, driven by many factors, including wars, discrimination and opportunity. Significant proportions of such people, and their descendents, constitute the modern populations of [[Eastern European Americans]] and [[Eastern European Canadians]] in the North American continent, and [[Eastern European Australians]] in Oceania.

Since the opening up of [[EU accession]] in the early 21st-century, millions of Eastern Europeans have migrated to other parts of Europe, especially to Central, Western, and Northern Europe; gaining access to the job markets of large economies in [[France]], [[Germany]] and the [[United Kingdom]] in particular.<ref name=\"goldenage2019\" />

[[Russell Deacon]] has written of the tension created in the mid-2000s, from Eastern Europeans emigrating to [[Welsh-speaking]] areas of Wales, with pressure group [[Cymuned]] lobbying the Welsh government to prioritize housing for locals, as a reactionary response.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=Devolution in the United Kingdom: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland
column10: quote=The problem of solely English-speaking or Eastern European people moving into predominantly Welsh-speaking areas has at times been a sensitive political issue. In 2001 a pressure group, [[Cymuned]] (Community), began to lobby the [[Welsh Assembly]] on issues relating to inward migration and the need to prioritise local housing for local people.}}</ref>

column3: John Harris]], outlined multiple years of apparent social problems created by large numbers of immigrants from Eastern Europe (and its bordering regions) which included reports of mafias, intra-ethnic conflicts, murders, as well as positive elements such as the revival of town centres.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Fear and anger in once-wealthy town divided by insecurity and immigration
column9: work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> In 2015, most Eastern Europeans living in [[Suffolk]] were young working-age adults.<ref>{{Cite article
column11: title=Health and Wellbeing Suffolk: Joint Strategic Needs Assessment - Migrants from Eastern Europe

column1: The majority of Eastern European people in Suffolk are young adults of working age. There are also children and some middle-aged and older people.}}</ref>
In 2018, British media reported growing concern for East European people affected by [[Brexit]].<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Concerns for eastern Europeans in Brexit ‘settled status’ plan

column1: Eastern Europeans arrived in large numbers to the United States during the 1880s and 1890s, settling in industry towns and cities, such as [[Cleveland, Ohio]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: quote=[[Cleveland, Ohio]], likewise, saw many Eastern Europeans choosing its city as their new home. While thousands of [[Germans]] often chose rural areas throughout Ohio as their new residence, they also settled in Cincinnati, Columbus and Cleveland. In fact, at the beginning of the 20th century, at least 50 percent of Cleveland residents were German. Over 75 percent of Cleveland’s population was foreign born by 1900.}}</ref> Implications of the ''[[War Measures Act]]'' in 1914, which authorized the designation of \"aliens of enemy nationality\", included Eastern European Canadians born or resident in Canada.<ref>{{cite book
column13: quote=The conflict between clashing loyalties for the Ukrainian and some other Central Eastern European Canadians was exacerbated by the war measures.}}</ref> Continuing into the 1920s, Eastern European Canadians faced persecution, along with [[African Canadians]], during economic recession and post-[[World War I]] unrest.<ref>{{cite book
column15: title=North of the Color Line: Migration and Black Resistance in Canada, 1870–1955
column21: quote=Throughout the 1920s, eastern European Canadians, like [[African Canadians]], became the country's convenient scapegoats for postwar labor unrest, peacetime economic recession, and urban demise.}}</ref> In the US from 1900 (until the [[Hart–Celler Act]] of 1965 ended it), the majority of immigration into the US was comprised of people arriving from Southern Europe, and large numbers of Eastern Europeans.<ref>{{cite book
column30: Southern]] and Eastern European Americans. After 1900, and prior to the [[1965 Immigration Act]], most immigrants to the United States came from southern and eastern European countries.}}</ref> This post-war period enabled Eastern European people to become significant percentages of US populations, in places such as the [[Pittsburg, Kansas]] mining community, nicknamed as the \"Little [[Balkans]]\".<ref>{{cite web
column35: quote=These local families were immigrants from many [[European nations]] who had brought their mining skills to southeast Kansas. Called \"Little Balkans,\" this region was home to [[French Americans
column36: French]], Italian, Swedish, Austrian, German, British, and Eastern European Americans who spoke many different languages.}}</ref>

column1: After the outbreak of [[World War II]], Eastern European citizens of Canada received training at [[Camp X]], many going on to serve their adoptive country in the [[Special Operations Executive]].<ref name=\"saturdaynight1982\">{{cite news
column5: quote=Similarly out of the mainstream were those central and eastern European Canadians, now condescendingly called \"ethnics.\" Of those who served with SOE , most were Yugoslavs who had immigrated to Canada in the 1920s and 1930s.}}</ref> In the US, however, Americans of Eastern European heritage faced government-enforced restrictions. Speaking to the [[Senate Judiciary Committee]], [[Russ Feingold]] acknowledged how \"Eastern European Americans were unfairly arrested, detained, interned, or relocated\" in a 2003 address.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Statement of The Honorable Russ Feingold
column10: quote=Thousands of [[German Americans]], Italian Americans, and Eastern European Americans were unfairly arrested, detained, interned, or relocated. Our government confiscated the personal property of many [[European Americans]] and restricted their travel rights.}}</ref>

column1: In both Canada and the United States, in the post-WWII period, politically active Eastern European people were forced to tread a careful line of diplomacy in both North American nations; demonstrating loyalty to their countries, while advocating for interventional policy which might aid people in their ancestral homelands.<ref>{{cite book
column3: title=Baltic Exiles and the U.S. Congress: Investigations and Legacies of the House Select Committee, 1953-1955
column9: quote=Politically motivated Eastern European Americans rejected the postwar political settlement in their former homelands. They were caught between promoting unrealistic foreign policy prescriptions in the American political spectrum, such as advocating the use of military force to roll back [[Communism]] in Eastern Europe, and having to demonstrate their loyaltly to the [[United States]].}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
column17: quote=Required by protocol to lay a bouquet of flowers at the \"[[Mound of Glory
column18: mound of glory]]\" - a war monument erected to the victories of the [[Red Army]] during the Second World War - he hastily deposited the flowers and quickly moved on, aware of the fact that his visit to the Soviet Union might antagonize the large number of eastern European Canadians living in Alberta.}}</ref>

column1: Eastern Europeans in Canada were shown to be underrepresented in professional occupations (and overrepresented in the [[personal service sector]]) by a 1961 census.<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Polish American Community Life: A Survey of Research
column6: publisher=[[Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences of America]]
column10: quote=Porter has shown that in 1961 Canadian Eastern European ethnics were underrepresented in professions and overrepresented in personal service. In the unskilled occupations Eastern Europeans reached the national mean in 1961.}}</ref> Cultural assimilation of Eastern Europeans was increasingly common in mid-20th-century North America. Professor [[Marc Shell]] has written regarding the Canadian government's enforcement of the [[anglicisation of names]].<ref>{{cite book
column13: title=Polio and Its Aftermath: The Paralysis of Culture
column19: quote=I became [[de jure]] Mark Shell in 1967 by means of an official [[Order of Council]]. (Such name changes were not untypical among assimilating Eastern Europeans in Canada.)}}</ref>

column1: In the US, Eastern Europeans were also gradually being accepted into mainstream American culture. Historian [[David Halberstam]], speaking in a [[New England Board of Higher Education]] interview, discussed how access to [[white society]] became plausible for the group.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Fall 2005 Connection: 50 Years of New England Higher Education and Economic Development
column5: publisher=[[New England Board of Higher Education]]
column6: quote= But in retrospect, it was narrower than we thought. We perceived ourselves in the ‘50s as a white society, and the breakthrough was mostly limited to people who were descendents of Italian-Americans, Eastern European Americans, children of Jewish immigrants.”}}</ref> Perhaps respresenting this social change best, the [[US Census Bureau]] found that the Eastern European  born in this time period (between 1956 and 1965) were indistinguishable, in education results, with [[British Americans]].  Eastern European Americans were found to have also outperformed US citizens of solely British heritage in the completion of [[bachelor's degrees]].<ref>{{cite book
column8: title=Sharing the Dream: White Males in a Multicultural America
column14: quote=The Census Bureau found that 55.9% of white men born between 1956 and 1965 had attended college and 25.5% of them had completed bachelor's degrees. However, the percentages had virtually converged for two groups in this cohort: men of solely [[British ancestry]] (66.3% and 31.8%, respectively) and Southern and Eastern European men (66.4% and 33.8%, respectively). Interestingly, these trends were reflected in the data for women too. While the [[Southern European Americans
column15: Southern]] and Eastern European Americans began to prosper in America, [[African Americans]] continued to suffer from discrimination and diminished life chances}}</ref>

column1: During the 1970s, the majority of Eastern Europeans resident in Canada lived in the country's main urban centers. The exception being those of Ukrainian heritage, who still mostly lived rurally.<ref>{{cite book
column9: quote=By 1971, the greatest percentage of all eastern European Canadians lived in the largest urban centers. The exception is the Ukrainians who live mainnly on the prairies.}}</ref> During this time, the [[Helsinki Accords]] were the cause of various political strife between the [[Ford administration]] and Eastern European people in the US.<ref>{{cite article
column10: title=Through the Looking Glass: The Helsinki Final Act and the 1976 Election for President
column15: quote=[[Helsinki Final Act]] became a point of contention between the [[White House]] and Eastern European Americans during Ford's election campaign}}</ref> Whereas, writing in 1980, Dr Roy Norton suggested that the group were appreciative of the role Canada played in the [[U.S. Helsinki Commission]], as well as the country's consistent criticizm of abuses to human rights in their ancestral lands.<ref>{{cite book
column19: title=Diplomatic Departures: The Conservative Era in Canadian Foreign Policy, 1984-93 (Canada and International Relations)
column23: chapter=Ethnic Groups and Conservative Foreign Policy
column25: quote=Most eastern European-Canadians appeared to be pleased with Canada's leadership at the [[Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe
column26: CSCE]] and on individual human rights cases; one community leader claimed he \"always felt [[Joe Clark]] was totally in tune with the position [he] was advocating\".}}</ref>

column1: Academic reesearch has been utilized in the study of Eastern European diaspora in North American.<ref>{{cite book
column3: title=European Economic Integration, WTO Membership, Immigration and Offshoring
column7: chapter=Restrictive Immigration Policy in Germany: Pains and Gains Foregone?
column9: quote=(iii) A “high education” scenario which assumes that the composition of the inflow equals the one observed for Eastern Europeans in Canada between 1995 and 2000.}}</ref> Professor Cezara O. Crisan has suggested, based on 2019 research at [[Purdue University Northwest]], that Eastern European Canadians are particularly likely to be politically and economically vested with the Eastern European nation that their heritage descends from.<ref>{{cite book
column11: title=The Legitimation Crisis of the Orthodox Church in the United States: From Assimilation to Incorporation
column15: chapter=Ethnic Groups and Conservative Foreign Policy
column17: quote=The individuals and families that resemble more the transnational features of immigration are mostly permanent residents of the host country, in this case, the United States (although a study of Eastern Europeans in Canada might reach similar findings.) There, while they reside physically in one place, they are involved economically, socially, and politcally in both the host and home country..}}</ref>

column1: In 2008, a genetic research investigation consecutively tested over five hundred Eastern European US citizens, in order to identify [[human leukocyte antigen]] alleles. The research, which was based at the [[Children's Hospital Oakland Research Institute]], contributed towards the creation of a [[hematopoietic stem cell]] register.<ref>{{cite study
column2: title=HLA-A, -B, -C, and -DRB1 allele and haplotype frequencies distinguish Eastern European Americans from the general European American population.
column6: quote=Sequence-based typing was used to identify [[human leukocyte antigen]] (HLA)-A, -B, -C, and -DRB1 alleles from 558 consecutively recruited US volunteers with Eastern European ancestry for an unrelated [[hematopoietic stem cell]] registry.}}</ref>

column1: [[Category:Ethnic groups in Europe]]","'''Eastern European people''' are a pan-ethnic group, or multi-ethnic regional grouping, and the inhabitants of [[Eastern Europe]]. '''East''' or '''Eastern Europeans''' can usually trace back full or partial heritage to [[Belarus]], [[Moldova]], [[European Russia]], [[Ukraine]] and other nations bordering with or otherwise ethnoculturally related to the region.

column2: East Slavic]] ethnicities, in its strictest geographical terms [[Moldova]] is the sole majority-Romance ethnic nation in the region; with significant numbers of [[Moldovans in Ukraine
column4: Romanians]] also native to other areas of Eastern Europe, such as in the [[Western Ukrainian]] borderland province [[Chernivtsi Oblast]] and parts of Russia.

column1: There are also many descriptions of Eastern Europeans which include ancestry from nations in [[Central Europe]], and countries of the [[South Slavs]], particularly in diasporic identification. There is a large Eastern European diaspora, with significant concentrations in North America ([[Eastern European Americans]] and [[Eastern European Canadians
column2: Canadians]]), as well as Oceania ([[Eastern European Australians]]).

column1: Eastern Europeans have been discussed academically, researched and reported on as a pan-ethnic group, which is most usually based on full or partial ancestry to Eastern Europe.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Closed borders, no shops? Been there, done that, say east Europeans
column8: quote=Eastern Europeans with strong memories of authoritarian [[Communist]] rule have taken a “been there, done that” attitude to the restrictions on free movement and shortages of some basic goods caused by the [[coronavirus pandemic]].}}</ref> This classification has also been extended, at times, to people from its bordering regions.<ref>{{cite book
column10: title=In the Clutches of the Kremlin – Canadian–East European Relations 1945–1962
column16: quote=Eastern European Canadians constitute an important base for Canadian domestic and foreign policies. Their influence varied during the different phases of immigration.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
column19: publisher=[[Australian Film, Television and Radio School]]
column22: quote=In the second chapter, he explores the concept of 'otherness' by denaturalising the privileged white gaze and examining representations of [[First Nations peoples]] and [[Asian Canadians
column23: Asian]] and Eastern European Canadians.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web

column1: The group can be broken down into further national subgroups such as [[Belarusians]], [[Ukrainians]] and [[Moldovans]].<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=Brunner and Suddarth's Textbook of Canadian Medical-Surgical Nursing
column11: quote=Examples of Canadian subcultures based on ethnicity include [[Native Canadians]], [[French Canadians]], and Eastern European Canadians. Each of these subcultures can be further divided.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
column13: title=Americans from Russia and Eastern Europe (New Americans)
column18: quote=Including people whose parents, grandparents, or other ancestors were born in [[Russia]] and Eastern Europe, the total number of Eastern European Americans is much higher.}}</ref> Despite their [[Central Europe
column19: Central European]] location, nations, including [[Hungary]] and the [[Czech Republic]], are sometimes used inclusively within parameters of heritage, when describing Eastern Europeans. This is particularly the case in diasporic terms.<ref>{{cite study
column26: quote=Of the eight faculty members present only one was born in Canada. The others included four \"Eastern European\" Canadians (of Ukrainian, Russian, [[Czechs
column37: quote=The retention, by immigrant communities, of the beliefs, values and rituals of their parent culture, whether British, [[Irish people
column38: Irish]], Mediterranean or Eastern European. Australian [[Catholicism]] is an obvious example of this phenomenon.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news
column40: title=Bodies pile up in South Africa as gangs fight over lucrative Australian drug trade
column47: AFP]] declined to comment about the Eastern European-Australian dual nationals working with South Africans}}</ref> Due to [[Slavs
column48: Slavic]] ethnic and cultural similarities, [[Yugoslavians]] have also occasionally been included in identification or reporting, despite [[Southeastern Europe]]'s distinct ethnocultural history.<ref name=\"saturdaynight1982\" />

column1: In 1964, the [[Assembly of Captive European Nations]] published material suggesting how, in the aftermath of [[World War II]], the \"Eastern European people were sealed off from the West and held down by Soviet-patterned police apparatuses\".<ref>{{cite news
column6: publisher=[[Assembly of Captive European Nations]]}}</ref> The attitudes of Eastern Europeans and their relationship to the state, government and society underwent transformation during the mid-20th century.<ref>{{cite book
column9: title=Recovering the Past. Eastern European Web Mining Platforms for Reconstructing Political Attitudes
column12: location=European Conference on Political Attitudes and Mentalities
column13: quote=During the past half century, the political attitude of the Eastern European people toward the state, government and society changed dramatically.}}</ref> During the 1980s, the poorer half of Eastern European populations earned an average of 30 percent of [[national income]] (which had dropped to around 17 percent by the end of the 2010s). Russia's richest one percent earned 3.5 percent of national income (by 2019, this had risen to 27 percent).<ref>{{Cite news
column15: title=Why it’s not easy being a young lefty in eastern Europe
column20: quote=Since [[the fall of the Berlin Wall]], despite the fact that eastern European states have became wealthier, the poor in these states have become poorer and the rich richer. In the 1980s, the total earnings of the poorer half of east Europeans was equivalent to 25-35% of national income. Since the end of communism, this figure has dropped to 17% in some countries. The most unequal country in the region is Russia, where the richest 1% now earns 27% of national income – a dramatic increase from 3.5% before the fall of the iron curtain.}}</ref>

column1: In 1989, historian [[Thaddeus Gromada]] claimed that non-Russian Eastern European people generally had more affinity with Western European culture than Russian culture.<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Report of the New Jersey Governor's Commission on Eastern European and Captive Nation History
column7: quote=There are great cultural differences between Russians and other Eastern European people. Most non-Russian East Europeans do not have any affinity with Russian culture. Rather, they feel more kinship with Western European culture}}</ref> Political scientists [[Ivan Krastev]] and [[Stephen Holmes (academic)
column8: Stephen Holmes]] have argued that this form of Western cultural aspiration drove the [[revolutions of 1989]] and acted as a shared mission for them.<ref>{{Cite news
column10: title=How liberalism became ‘the god that failed’ in eastern Europe
column17: quote=When the [[cold war]] ended, racing to join [[Western world
column18: the west]] was the shared mission of central and eastern Europeans. Indeed, becoming indistinguishably western was arguably the principal aim of the [[revolutions of 1989]].}}</ref> For his conduct during this period, politican [[Julian Knight (politician)
column19: Julian Knight]] has written that Soviet leader [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] deserves credit for understanding how the [[Cold War]] was impoverishing both Russians and other Eastern Europeans, and for helping to facilitate its end.<ref>{{cite book
column25: chapter=Chapter 24: Ten Political Events that Shaped the Modern World
column27: quote=Much of the credit for the peaceful transference of former eastern European communist regimes to democracies belongs to the Soviet leader of the late 1980s and early 1990s, [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]. Although a communist, he saw that the [[Cold War]] between the West and East was impoverishing his own and other eastern European people.}}</ref> Historian [[Dan Stone (historian)
column28: Dan Stone]] has suggested President [[George H. W. Bush]]'s self-imposed distancing from European politics during this time \"inadvertently gave the Eastern European people the space they needed to carry out their revolutions\".<ref>{{cite book
column31: title=Goodbye to All That?: The Story of Europe Since 1945

column1: During the economic reforms of the 1990s, as the region partially fell away from the economic sphere of Russia, Eastern Europeans suffered financially with, at first, growing costs and less disposable income.<ref>{{cite book
column3: title=Effects of Eastern European Reforms on World Trade in Forest Products
column6: quote=The Eastern European people were faced with the dual problem of having less money to spend while at the same time facing increasingly high prices on virtually all goods and services.}}</ref> In the 21st-century, the process of [[EU enlargement]] has occasionally exposed cultural differences in between Western and Eastern Europeans, with the Soviet history of the region influencing the latter's political worldviews.<ref>{{cite book
column8: title=Anti-liberal Europe: A Neglected Story of Europeanization
column14: European enlargement]] process since the end of the [[Cold War]] has brought to the surface significant differences in opinions concerning the future of the union between so-called Old and New Europe. This could be seen as an indication that the communist conception of Europe did have an impact on the Eastern European people.}}</ref>

column1: In 2019, a [[Pew Research Center]] survey found that between 58 and 65 percent of Eastern Europeans felt positively about [[living standards]], education and [[national pride]] in the post-Communist era.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=30 years after communism, eastern Europe divided on democracy's impact
column8: quote=Asked how they felt their countries had advanced, central and eastern Europeans were most positive about education (65%), living standards (61%) and national pride (58%). They were less happy about law and order (44%) and family values (41%), and a majority (53%) said healthcare had got worse in the post-communist era.}}</ref> In the same year, it was reported that the group were living close to ten years longer on avergage, since 1990, with longevity recorded as much as 10 percent higher for some.<ref name=\"goldenage2019\">{{Cite news
column10: title='This is the golden age': eastern Europe's extraordinary 30-year revival
column15: quote=Since then, longevity has surged as much as 10% in some parts of the region, and east Europeans are now more likely to be nearer 80 than 70 when they die.}}</ref>

column1: In 2020, it was reported how the [[European Union]]'s policy of free movement had enabled or encouraged millions of Eastern Europeans to return home from Germany, and other large European economies, after job losses created by the [[coronavirus pandemic]].<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=After coronavirus: how will Europe rebuild?
column8: quote=If Germany’s success in handling the pandemic is partly down to an army of migrant doctors and nurses, it should not be to the detriment of central and eastern Europe. Free movement of labour has also, paradoxically, led to the return home of millions of eastern Europeans.}}</ref>

column9: quote=he long transition processes from the communist to democratic regimes made almost all Eastern European people and their countries experience during the past two decades the need to explain their choices, values, beliefs, norms, attitudes, symbols, grievances or prejudices, their institutions, regimes, and discourses.}}</ref>

column3: title=In/visibly different: Melania Trump and the othering of Eastern European women in US culture
column8: quote=The view on Eastern European people as unable to produce original thinking, and accordingly stealing from their Western peers, does not only confirm their questionable morals and character, it also confirms the superiority of Western (here US) thinking, culture, and being.}}</ref> A 2019 [[Roskilde University]] study was critical of discriminatory Danish media representations of Eastern European people, which it described as portraying them as a racially inferior working-class, prone to criminality, who's 'otherness' was to be subsumed by integration into a \"Danish '[[whiteness studies

column17: quote=They are presented as an ‘inferior race’ consisting of ‘cheap labor’ and criminals, who ‘invade’ Denmark and cause economical and security problems for Danish population. column30: Southern]] and Eastern European Americans. After 1900, and prior to the [[1965 Immigration Act]], most immigrants to the United States came from southern and eastern European countries.}}</ref> This post-war period enabled Eastern European people to become significant percentages of US populations, in places such as the [[Pittsburg, Kansas]] mining community, nicknamed as the \"Little [[Balkans]]\".<ref>{{cite web
column35: quote=These local families were immigrants from many [[European nations]] who had brought their mining skills to southeast Kansas. Called \"Little Balkans,\" this region was home to [[French Americans
column36: French]], Italian, Swedish, Austrian, German, British, and Eastern European Americans who spoke many different languages.}}</ref>

column1: After the outbreak of [[World War II]], Eastern European citizens of Canada received training at [[Camp X]], many going on to serve their adoptive country in the [[Special Operations Executive]].<ref name=\"saturdaynight1982\">{{cite news
column5: quote=Similarly out of the mainstream were those central and eastern European Canadians, now condescendingly called \"ethnics.\" Of those who served with SOE , most were Yugoslavs who had immigrated to Canada in the 1920s and 1930s.}}</ref> In the US, however, Americans of Eastern European heritage faced government-enforced restrictions. Speaking to the [[Senate Judiciary Committee]], [[Russ Feingold]] acknowledged how \"Eastern European Americans were unfairly arrested, detained, interned, or relocated\" in a 2003 address.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Statement of The Honorable Russ Feingold
column10: quote=Thousands of [[German Americans]], Italian Americans, and Eastern European Americans were unfairly arrested, detained, interned, or relocated. Our government confiscated the personal property of many [[European Americans]] and restricted their travel rights.}}</ref>

column1: In both Canada and the United States, in the post-WWII period, politically active Eastern European people were forced to tread a careful line of diplomacy in both North American nations; demonstrating loyalty to their countries, while advocating for interventional policy which might aid people in their ancestral homelands.<ref>{{cite book
column3: title=Baltic Exiles and the U.S. Congress: Investigations and Legacies of the House Select Committee, 1953-1955
column9: quote=Politically motivated Eastern European Americans rejected the postwar political settlement in their former homelands. They were caught between promoting unrealistic foreign policy prescriptions in the American political spectrum, such as advocating the use of military force to roll back [[Communism]] in Eastern Europe, and having to demonstrate their loyaltly to the [[United States]].}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
column17: quote=Required by protocol to lay a bouquet of flowers at the \"[[Mound of Glory
column18: mound of glory]]\" - a war monument erected to the victories of the [[Red Army]] during the Second World War - he hastily deposited the flowers and quickly moved on, aware of the fact that his visit to the Soviet Union might antagonize the large number of eastern European Canadians living in Alberta.}}</ref>

column1: Eastern Europeans in Canada were shown to be underrepresented in professional occupations (and overrepresented in the [[personal service sector]]) by a 1961 census.<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Polish American Community Life: A Survey of Research
column6: publisher=[[Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences of America]]
column10: quote=Porter has shown that in 1961 Canadian Eastern European ethnics were underrepresented in professions and overrepresented in personal service. In the unskilled occupations Eastern Europeans reached the national mean in 1961.}}</ref> Cultural assimilation of Eastern Europeans was increasingly common in mid-20th-century North America. Professor [[Marc Shell]] has written regarding the Canadian government's enforcement of the [[anglicisation of names]].<ref>{{cite book
column13: title=Polio and Its Aftermath: The Paralysis of Culture
column19: quote=I became [[de jure]] Mark Shell in 1967 by means of an official [[Order of Council]]. (Such name changes were not untypical among assimilating Eastern Europeans in Canada.)}}</ref>

column1: In the US, Eastern Europeans were also gradually being accepted into mainstream American culture. Historian [[David Halberstam]], speaking in a [[New England Board of Higher Education]] interview, discussed how access to [[white society]] became plausible for the group.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Fall 2005 Connection: 50 Years of New England Higher Education and Economic Development
column5: publisher=[[New England Board of Higher Education]]
column6: quote= But in retrospect, it was narrower than we thought. We perceived ourselves in the ‘50s as a white society, and the breakthrough was mostly limited to people who were descendents of Italian-Americans, Eastern European Americans, children of Jewish immigrants.”}}</ref> Perhaps respresenting this social change best, the [[US Census Bureau]] found that the Eastern European  born in this time period (between 1956 and 1965) were indistinguishable, in education results, with [[British Americans]].  Eastern European Americans were found to have also outperformed US citizens of solely British heritage in the completion of [[bachelor's degrees]].<ref>{{cite book
column8: title=Sharing the Dream: White Males in a Multicultural America
column14: quote=The Census Bureau found that 55.9% of white men born between 1956 and 1965 had attended college and 25.5% of them had completed bachelor's degrees. However, the percentages had virtually converged for two groups in this cohort: men of solely [[British ancestry]] (66.3% and 31.8%, respectively) and Southern and Eastern European men (66.4% and 33.8%, respectively). Interestingly, these trends were reflected in the data for women too. While the [[Southern European Americans
column15: Southern]] and Eastern European Americans began to prosper in America, [[African Americans]] continued to suffer from discrimination and diminished life chances}}</ref>

column1: During the 1970s, the majority of Eastern Europeans resident in Canada lived in the country's main urban centers. The exception being those of Ukrainian heritage, who still mostly lived rurally.<ref>{{cite book
column9: quote=By 1971, the greatest percentage of all eastern European Canadians lived in the largest urban centers. The exception is the Ukrainians who live mainnly on the prairies.}}</ref> During this time, the [[Helsinki Accords]] were the cause of various political strife between the [[Ford administration]] and Eastern European people in the US.<ref>{{cite article
column10: title=Through the Looking Glass: The Helsinki Final Act and the 1976 Election for President
column15: quote=[[Helsinki Final Act]] became a point of contention between the [[White House]] and Eastern European Americans during Ford's election campaign}}</ref> Whereas, writing in 1980, Dr Roy Norton suggested that the group were appreciative of the role Canada played in the [[U.S. Helsinki Commission]], as well as the country's consistent criticizm of abuses to human rights in their ancestral lands.<ref>{{cite book
column19: title=Diplomatic Departures: The Conservative Era in Canadian Foreign Policy, 1984-93 (Canada and International Relations)
column23: chapter=Ethnic Groups and Conservative Foreign Policy
column25: quote=Most eastern European-Canadians appeared to be pleased with Canada's leadership at the [[Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe
column26: CSCE]] and on individual human rights cases; one community leader claimed he \"always felt [[Joe Clark]] was totally in tune with the position [he] was advocating\".}}</ref>

column1: Academic reesearch has been utilized in the study of Eastern European diaspora in North American.<ref>{{cite book
column3: title=European Economic Integration, WTO Membership, Immigration and Offshoring
column7: chapter=Restrictive Immigration Policy in Germany: Pains and Gains Foregone?
column9: quote=(iii) A “high education” scenario which assumes that the composition of the inflow equals the one observed for Eastern Europeans in Canada between 1995 and 2000.}}</ref> Professor Cezara O. Crisan has suggested, based on 2019 research at [[Purdue University Northwest]], that Eastern European Canadians are particularly likely to be politically and economically vested with the Eastern European nation that their heritage descends from.<ref>{{cite book
column11: title=The Legitimation Crisis of the Orthodox Church in the United States: From Assimilation to Incorporation
column15: chapter=Ethnic Groups and Conservative Foreign Policy
column17: quote=The individuals and families that resemble more the transnational features of immigration are mostly permanent residents of the host country, in this case, the United States (although a study of Eastern Europeans in Canada might reach similar findings.) There, while they reside physically in one place, they are involved economically, socially, and politcally in both the host and home country..}}</ref>

column1: In 2008, a genetic research investigation consecutively tested over five hundred Eastern European US citizens, in order to identify [[human leukocyte antigen]] alleles. The research, which was based at the [[Children's Hospital Oakland Research Institute]], contributed towards the creation of a [[hematopoietic stem cell]] register.<ref>{{cite study
column2: title=HLA-A, -B, -C, and -DRB1 allele and haplotype frequencies distinguish Eastern European Americans from the general European American population.
column6: quote=Sequence-based typing was used to identify [[human leukocyte antigen]] (HLA)-A, -B, -C, and -DRB1 alleles from 558 consecutively recruited US volunteers with Eastern European ancestry for an unrelated [[hematopoietic stem cell]] registry.}}</ref>

column1: '''Backlash (2008)''' was a [[professional wrestling]] [[pay-per-view]] (PPV) [[List of WWE pay-per-view events
column2: event]] produced by [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE). It took place on April 27, 2008, at the [[1st Mariner Arena]] in [[Baltimore
column3: Baltimore, Maryland]]. Following WrestleMania, all pay-per-views became tri-branded. It was the tenth annual event under the [[WWE Backlash
column4: Backlash]] name and starred [[List of World Wrestling Entertainment employees

column2: professional wrestling matches]] were scheduled on the event's [[Card (sports)
column3: card]], which featured a supercard, a scheduling of more than one [[Card (sports)#Main event
column4: main event]]. The first was a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches
column5: Fatal 4-Way elimination]] for the [[WWE Championship]] match featuring wrestlers from the Raw brand, in which all four men fought in the ring at the same time, with competitors being eliminated by [[Pin (professional wrestling)
column7: submission]]. [[Triple H]] defeated WWE Champion [[Randy Orton]], [[John Cena]], and [[John Layfield
column8: John \"Bradshaw\" Layfield]] to win the championship. The other main event featured wrestlers from the SmackDown brand, in which defending [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)
column9: World Heavyweight Champion]] [[The Undertaker]] defeated challenger [[Edge (wrestler)
column10: Edge]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches
column11: standard wrestling match]], also known as a singles match. The main event from the ECW brand was a standard match in which defending [[ECW Championship
column14: Chavo Guerrero]]. In addition, a featured bout was scheduled on the undercard, in which [[Shawn Michaels]] defeated [[Dave Bautista

column1: Backlash (2008) had an attendance of approximately 11,277 and received 200,000 buys, more than the [[Backlash (2007)
column3: title=World Wrestling Entertainment, Inc. Reports 2008 Second Quarter Results
column7: accessdate=2008-08-06}}</ref> When the event was released on [[DVD]], it reached a peak position of second on ''[[Billboard (magazine)
column8: Billboard]]'''s Recreational Sports DVD Sales Chart.

column4: [[John Cena]] competed in the [[WWE Championship]] match.]]

column2: professional wrestling matches]] with outcomes predetermined by WWE script writers. The matches featured wrestlers portraying their [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Gimmick
column3: characters]] in planned storylines that took place before, during and after the event. All wrestlers were from one of the WWE's brands – [[SmackDown (WWE brand)
column7: storyline divisions]] in which WWE assigned its employees.

column1: Wrestlers from Raw were featured in the [[Card (sports)#Main event
column2: main event]] at Backlash: a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches
column3: fatal 4-way elimination]] match, in which four men wrestled each other and can be eliminated only by [[Pin (professional wrestling)
column5: submission]]. The match was contested for the [[WWE Championship]], featuring the champion, [[Randy Orton]], defending against [[Triple H]], [[John Cena]], and [[John Layfield
column6: John \"Bradshaw\" Layfield]] (JBL). The buildup to the match began at [[WrestleMania XXIV]], where Randy Orton defended his title against Triple H and John Cena in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches
column7: Triple Threat match]], in which the three men competed against each other, and the first man to score a pinfall or submission would win. Orton won the match, retaining the title after pinning Cena.<ref name=\"WM24-1\">{{cite web
column19: title=Mayweather, Orton survive Mania; Edge, Flair don't
column23: accessdate=2009-01-11}}</ref> On the following night's episode of ''Raw'', with the WWE Championship shining on his shoulder, Randy Orton crowed about defeating both Triple H and John Cena at WrestleMania, declaring his reign as champion the \"Age of Orton\". But John \"Bradshaw\" Layfield had other ideas, telling Orton that he deserved a title match as a reward for proving that he was the toughest Superstar on Raw in his [[Hardcore wrestling
column25: Finlay]] also at WrestleMania. On the following week's episode of ''Raw'', WWE Champion Randy Orton began the night believing he would go one-on-one with JBL at Backlash, but the tide quickly turned on him. Due to Triple H's complaint about himself being [[Professional wrestling attacks#Football kick
column26: kicked]] in the head by Orton when he was about to pin Cena to win the WWE title at Wrestlemania, [[WWE Raw
column29: William Regal]] placed Triple H into a [[Professional wrestling match types#Handicap match
column30: Handicap match]] against Orton & JBL, and when Triple H won, Regal made the [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches
column31: Triple Threat match]] for the title. Not to be outdone, John Cena also pleaded his case to Regal, who gave him the same Handicap Match ultimatum. After Orton's intended interference failed, Cena pulled out the win, thus, the championship match at Backlash became a Fatal Four Way starring three former WWE Champions challenging Orton. On the following week's episode of ''Raw'', after his victory over William Regal, Orton felt compelled to meddle in the bout between Triple H and JBL. In an attempt at eliminating Triple H from Backlash, Orton ran in and nearly took off Triple H's head. He administered an [[Cutter (professional wrestling)#Jumping cutter
column32: RKO]] before then teaming with JBL against him. As Orton was set to punt Triple H's noggin again, however, JBL turned on him and laid him out with a vicious [[Professional wrestling attacks#Clothesline

column2: feud]] heading into Backlash on the SmackDown brand was between [[The Undertaker]] and [[Edge (wrestler)
column4: World Heavyweight Championship]]. In February, at [[No Way Out (2008)
column5: No Way Out]], Undertaker won an [[Elimination Chamber]] match to become the number one contender to the World Heavyweight Championship at [[WrestleMania XXIV]].<ref>{{cite web
column12: date=2008-02-17}}</ref> At WrestleMania, Undertaker defeated Edge to win the World Heavyweight Championship and extend his WrestleMania undefeated streak to 16–0.<ref>{{cite web
column19: accessdate=2008-04-05}}</ref> On the April 4, 2008 episode of ''SmackDown'', [[Professional wrestling authority figures#General managers 2
column20: SmackDown General Manager]] [[Vickie Guerrero]] [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Book
column21: booked]] a WrestleMania rematch between Undertaker and Edge for the World Heavyweight Championship at Backlash.<ref name=\"4/04 SmackDown\">{{cite web

column2: SmackDown]] heading into Backlash was between [[Matt Hardy]] and [[Montel Vontavious Porter
column3: MVP]]. On the November 16th, 2007 edition of [[WWE SmackDown
column4: SmackDown]] after failing to regain the [[WWE Tag Team Championship
column5: Tag Team Championship]] from John Morrison and The Miz, MVP attacked Matt Hardy targeting and injuring his knee. The feud would start again at [[WrestleMania XXIV]] where Matt Hardy cost MVP the Money in the Bank Ladder Match by performing a Twist of Fate at the top of the ladder. Hardy would then face MVP on the April 4th, 2008 edition of SmackDown in a non-title match, which he won. It was confirmed on the next SmackDown that Matt Hardy would face MVP for the [[WWE United States Championship

column6: Edge]], who faced [[The Undertaker]] for the [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)

column1: The primary feud on the ECW brand was between [[Kane (wrestler)
column3: Chavo Guerrero]], with the two battling over the [[ECW Championship]]. Before WrestleMania XXIV aired live on pay-per-view, Kane won a 24-Man [[Battle royal (professional wrestling)
column4: Battle Royal]] to earn an ECW Championship match against Chavo Guerrero later that night.<ref name=\"'Mania XXIV\">{{cite web
column12: url-status= live}}</ref> Kane would go on to defeat Guerrero and become the new ECW Champion.<ref name=\"'Mania XXIV\"/> On the April 4 episode of ''SmackDown!'', SmackDown! General Manager Vickie Guerrero booked Kane to defend the ECW Championship against Chavo Guerrero at Backlash.<ref name=\"4/04 SmackDown\"/> The feud intensified on the April 8 episode of ''[[ECW (WWE)
column13: ECW]]'', where during a contract signing for Backlash, Guerrero, with assistance from [[Justin LaRouche
column14: Bam Neeley]], [[Curt Hawkins and Zack Ryder]], delivered a [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Frog splash
column15: Frog splash]] on Kane through a [[Table (furniture)
column23: url-status= live}}</ref> Two weeks later on April 22, 2008, the feud again intensified during an episode of the ''[[WWE Friday Night SmackDown#Recurring segments
column25: Edge]], Hawkins, Ryder, and Neeley ganged up against Kane. The gang-up allowed Guerrero to attack Kane with a [[Folding chair

column1: Another feud leading up to Backlash was between [[Shawn Michaels]] and [[Dave Bautista
column2: Batista]]. Upset over the retirement of [[Ric Flair]] at the hands of Michaels at WrestleMania XXIV, Batista interrupted Michaels' address on the April 4 episode of ''SmackDown!'' and called him a \"selfish\" person for what he did at WrestleMania. Batista blamed Michaels for not lying down for Flair and thus protecting his career instead of retiring him. Michaels defended his actions by saying Flair had called upon him to bring his best to WrestleMania, which he did. The conflict continued on an episode of [[Chris Jericho]]'s \"[[WWE Raw#Recurring segments
column3: Highlight Reel]]\" interview segment that featured both men on the April 7 episode of ''Raw''. Following another tense verbal standoff, Batista left the ring saying he had something in store for Michaels. Moments later, Raw General Manager William Regal said he had confirmed a match with SmackDown General Manager Vickie Guerrero between Michaels and Batista at Backlash. In addition, the following week Jericho had a confrontation with Shawn Michaels who ended up kicking Jericho in the face. Frustrated, Jericho went to Regal in an effort to possibly add himself to the match. Regal did indeed add Jericho to the match, but not as a competitor. Instead he announced Jericho as a [[Professional wrestling match types#Special referee
column4: Special Guest Referee]] for the match.

column2: class=wikitable style=\"font-size:90%; margin: 0.5em 0 0.5em 1em; float: right; clear: right;\"

column1: Before the event began and aired [[Live television
column2: live]] on [[pay-per-view]], a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Dark match
column3: dark match]] was featured in which [[WWE Tag Team Championship (2002–2010)
column4: WWE Tag Team Champions]] [[John Morrison and The Miz]] defeated [[James Yun
column5: Jimmy Wang Yang]] and [[Shannon Moore]].<ref name=\"Facts\"/>

column1: Following the dark match, the pay-per-view event began with a standard match for the [[WWE United States Championship]], in which the champion, [[Montel Vontavious Porter]] (MVP) defended his title against [[Matt Hardy]]. Throughout the match, both Hardy and MVP performed a number of offensive maneuvers on each other, but Hardy eventually gained the advantage when MVP charged Hardy and Hardy dodged him, followed by Hardy performing a [[Cutter (professional wrestling)#Twist of Fate
column2: Twist of Fate]], on MVP. He followed this with a [[Pin (professional wrestling)#Cover
column3: cover]] for a successful pinfall, giving Hardy the victory and the championship.<ref name=\"WrestleView\">{{cite web

column1: The second bout was a standard match for the [[ECW Championship]], in which the champion, [[Kane (wrestler)
column2: Kane]] defended his title against [[Chavo Guerrero, Jr.
column3: Chavo Guerrero]], who was accompanied by [[Justin LaRouche
column4: Bam Neely]]. Guerrero spent much of the match attacking Kane's leg, and toward the end of the match he performed a [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Frog splash
column5: Frog Splash]], on Kane. Before he could cover Kane for a pinfall, however, Kane [[chokeslam]]ed him. Kane then covered Guerrero for a pinfall, thus retaining his championship.<ref name=\"WrestleView\"/><ref name=\"PWTorch\">{{cite web
column7: title=Keller's WWE Backlash PPV Report 4/27: Ongoing \"virtual time\" coverage of live PPV event

column5: The Big Show]] and [[The Great Khali]] staring at each other before their match]]

column2: The Big Show]] against [[The Great Khali]] in a standard match. Both men wrestled inconclusively until The Big Show performed a [[body slam]] onto Khali, after which Khali attempted to perform a [[Chokeslam#Two handed chokeslam
column3: two handed chokeslam]] on The Big Show. The Big Show countered, however, and delivered a chokeslam to Khali. He then covered him for a successful pinfall, winning the match.<ref name=\"Slam\"/><ref name=\"PWTorch\"/>

column1: The fourth match was a standard match between [[Dave Bautista
column2: Batista]] and [[Shawn Michaels]], with [[Chris Jericho]] as a [[Professional wrestling match types#Special referee
column3: special guest referee]]. The men performed a number of offensive moves on one another throughout the match, including Shawn Michaels performing a [[Professional wrestling holds#Crossface
column4: crossface]] on Batista. The match also briefly went to the ringside area, where the ringpost was used as a weapon by Michaels. The end of the match came when Batista lifted Michaels for a [[powerbomb]], the Batista Bomb. Michaels, however, escaped from the hold in the air, and when he fell, suffered a [[kayfabe
column5: storyline]] knee injury, which caused Jericho to check on Michaels and stop Batista from acting. Michaels eventually got to his feet, and used [[superkick
column6: Sweet Chin Music]] on Batista. Michaels then covered Batista for a successful pinfall, winning the match. Afterward, Michaels returned to the backstage area [[Sell (professional wrestling)

column1: The next contest was a twelve-[[WWE Diva
column2: Diva]] [[Professional wrestling tag team match types
column3: tag team match]] featuring the team of [[Beth Phoenix]], [[Melina Perez
column7: Layla]], and [[Jillian Hall]] against the team of [[Mickie James]], [[Ashley Massaro
column10: Cherry]]. The match began with Michelle McCool against Beth Phoenix, and over the course of the match, all of the women participated in the contest. The end of the match came when Beth Phoenix performed a [[Suplex#Fisherman suplex
column11: fisherman suplex]] on Ashley, and then covered her for a successful pin, giving her team the victory.<ref name=\"Slam\"/><ref name=\"PWTorch\"/>

column1: The sixth match of the event was a standard match for the [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)
column2: World Heavyweight Championship]], in which the champion, [[The Undertaker]], defended his title against [[Edge (wrestler)
column3: Edge]]. The match was contested back and forth between the two men, with the early portions of the match featuring The Undertaker controlling much of the action. Edge eventually took an advantage when he exposed the turnbuckle in the corner, and The Undertaker ran head first into it. [[Curt Hawkins and Zack Ryder
column4: Curt Hawkins]] then struck The Undertaker with the World Heavyweight Championship belt, which was followed by an unsuccessful cover by Edge.  Edge then attempted to hit Undertaker with a [[Professional wrestling attacks#Spear
column5: spear]], but The Undertaker countered the maneuver hitting Edge with a  [[DDT (professional wrestling)
column7: Zack Ryder]] then attempted to interfere on behalf of Edge, but The Undertaker threw Edge into Ryder and then caught Edge in an attempted [[Piledriver (professional wrestling)#Tombstone piledriver
column8: Tombstone Piledriver]], in which The Undertaker would have held Edge upside down and knelt, driving Edge's head into the mat. Edge countered the move, however, into a [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Sunset flip
column9: sunset flip]]. While Edge was pinning The Undertaker, however, The Undertaker performed a [[gogoplata]] submission hold, which caused Edge to [[Professional wrestling#Submission
column10: submit]], giving The Undertaker the victory. The Undertaker continued to apply the hold after the match ended, injuring (in storyline) Edge. Edge was removed from the ring on a stretcher by medics, making his injury appear realistic.<ref name=\"WrestleView\"/><ref name=\"PWTorch\"/>

column4: [[Randy Orton]] who lost the [[WWE Championship]] to [[Triple H]]]]

column1: The main event was a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches
column2: four-way elimination]] match for the [[WWE Championship]], in which the champion, [[Randy Orton]], defended his title against [[Triple H]], [[John Cena]], and [[John Layfield
column3: John \"Bradshaw\" Layfield]] (JBL). The match began with Orton attempting to attack JBL, but JBL countered and threw Orton out of the ring.  JBL then attacked Cena, before being attacked by Triple H.  Cena then attempted to [[Professional wrestling throws#Irish whip
column4: swing Triple H by the arm]] into the corner, but Triple H reversed the move and sent Cena outside of the ring. Triple H and JBL then fought in the ring, while Cena and Orton fought outside. Cena was later sent off the ring apron into the ''Raw'' announcer's table, and Orton and JBL teamed up to attack Triple H in the ring. Triple H eventually hit both of them with a [[Professional wrestling attacks#Clothesline
column5: clothesline]], and JBL went to the outside of the ring while Triple H and Orton fought inside. Triple H later went outside of the ring and fought with JBL, while Cena returned to the ring and fought with Orton. After the men fought each other for several minutes, Cena put JBL in the [[Professional wrestling holds#Sleeper hold
column6: STFU]]. This caused JBL to submit, eliminating him from the match. Immediately following JBL's submission, Orton [[Professional wrestling attacks#Punt
column7: kicked Cena in the head]], which he followed with a cover for a pinfall, eliminating Cena from the match. Triple H and Orton then began to fight on the outside of the ring, with Orton taking control and sending Triple H back into the ring, where he dominated Triple H with a series of maneuvers for several minutes before Triple H struck Orton with his knee. The men fought outside the ring again, and when they returned, they fought for several more minutes until Orton performed a [[Cutter (professional wrestling)#Jumping cutter
column8: jumping cutter]], or RKO, on Triple H. Orton would then try to pin Triple H, only to get a two count. Orton then attempted to kick Triple H in the head, but Triple H dodged the maneuver and both men would counter their finishers until Triple H performed a [[Facebuster#Double underhook facebuster
column9: Pedigree]] on Orton followed by a successful pin-fall, thus earning him his twelfth world championship.<ref name=\"Slam\"/><ref name=\"PWTorch\"/>

column1: The feud between [[Triple H]] and [[Randy Orton]] continued. On the April 28 episode of ''Raw'', Orton challenged Triple H for the [[WWE Championship]] later on in the night.<ref name=\"WWEPreview\">{{cite web
column16: William Regal]] stopped the match midway through, however, and later [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Book
column17: booked]] the two in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Cages
column18: Steel Cage match]] for the title at [[Judgment Day (2008)

column1: On the May 2 episode of ''[[WWE SmackDown
column2: SmackDown]]'', [[Vickie Guerrero]] cancelled a scheduled World Title match between Undertaker and [[The Great Khali]] and stripped [[The Undertaker]] of the [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)
column3: World Heavyweight Championship]], and [[Curt Hawkins and Zack Ryder]] stole the physical belt and handed it to Guerrero. The next week on ''SmackDown'', Guerrero booked a \"Championship Chase\" where the winner would face the Undertaker for the vacant World Championship at Judgment Day. Batista originally won, but his victory was cut short after Guerrero came out and announced that Edge had been medically cleared and would be able to compete. Thus, the match continued, and Edge defeated Batista, gaining the championship match at Judgment Day.

column1: The following night on ''Raw'', Mickie James' team defeated Beth Phoenix's team in a 12-Diva rematch from Backlash. The following week, James retained the Women's Championship against Phoenix in a lumberjill match, with the win coming after the evil Melina attempted to strike James with her boot, but accidentally struck Phoenix. The alliance between Phoenix and Melina ended a week later, and the two Divas would face James at Judgment Day for the title.

The event had a final attendance of 11,277. [[Canadian Online Explorer]]<nowiki>'</nowiki>s professional wrestling section rated the entire event a 6 out of 10 stars.<ref name=\"Slam\" /> The Fatal Four-Way main event match from the Raw brand was rated a 6 out of 10 stars, while the SmackDown brand's main event, a standard match for the World Heavyweight Championship, was rated an 8 out of 10 stars, and The Shawn Michaels/Batista match was rated the highest with having an 8.5 out of 10.<ref name=\"Slam\" /> The event was released on [[DVD]] on May 27, 2008<ref>{{cite web
column8: archivedate=February 5, 2009}}</ref> by [[Sony Music Entertainment]]. The DVD reached second on ''[[Billboard (magazine)
column9: Billboard]]'''s DVD Sales Chart for recreational sports during the week of June 21, 2008, and remained on the chart until the week of July 26, 2008, when it ranked 13.<ref>{{cite web

column1: '''Backlash (2008)''' was a [[professional wrestling]] [[pay-per-view]] (PPV) [[List of WWE pay-per-view events
column2: event]] produced by [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE). It took place on April 27, 2008, at the [[1st Mariner Arena]] in [[Baltimore
column3: Baltimore, Maryland]]. Following WrestleMania, all pay-per-views became tri-branded. It was the tenth annual event under the [[WWE Backlash

column2: professional wrestling matches]] with outcomes predetermined by WWE script writers. The matches featured wrestlers portraying their [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Gimmick

column1: Wrestlers from Raw were featured in the [[Card (sports)#Main event
column2: main event]] at Backlash: a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches
column3: fatal 4-way elimination]] match, in which four men wrestled each other and can be eliminated only by [[Pin (professional wrestling)
column5: submission]]. The match was contested for the [[WWE Championship]], featuring the champion, [[Randy Orton]], defending against [[Triple H]], [[John Cena]], and [[John Layfield
column6: John \"Bradshaw\" Layfield]] (JBL). The buildup to the match began at [[WrestleMania XXIV]], where Randy Orton defended his title against Triple H and John Cena in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches
column7: Triple Threat match]], in which the three men competed against each other, and the first man to score a pinfall or submission would win. Orton won the match, retaining the title after pinning Cena.<ref name=\"WM24-1\">{{cite web
column19: title=Mayweather, Orton survive Mania; Edge, Flair don't
column23: accessdate=2009-01-11}}</ref> On the following night's episode of ''Raw'', with the WWE Championship shining on his shoulder, Randy Orton crowed about defeating both Triple H and John Cena at WrestleMania, declaring his reign as champion the \"Age of Orton\". But John \"Bradshaw\" Layfield had other ideas, telling Orton that he deserved a title match as a reward for proving that he was the toughest Superstar on Raw in his [[Hardcore wrestling
column25: Finlay]] also at WrestleMania. On the following week's episode of ''Raw'', WWE Champion Randy Orton began the night believing he would go one-on-one with JBL at Backlash, but the tide quickly turned on him. Due to Triple H's complaint about himself being [[Professional wrestling attacks#Football kick
column26: kicked]] in the head by Orton when he was about to pin Cena to win the WWE title at Wrestlemania, [[WWE Raw
column29: William Regal]] placed Triple H into a [[Professional wrestling match types#Handicap match
column30: Handicap match]] against Orton & JBL, and when Triple H won, Regal made the [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches
column31: Triple Threat match]] for the title. Not to be outdone, John Cena also pleaded his case to Regal, who gave him the same Handicap Match ultimatum. After Orton's intended interference failed, Cena pulled out the win, thus, the championship match at Backlash became a Fatal Four Way starring three former WWE Champions challenging Orton. On the following week's episode of ''Raw'', after his victory over William Regal, Orton felt compelled to meddle in the bout between Triple H and JBL. In an attempt at eliminating Triple H from Backlash, Orton ran in and nearly took off Triple H's head. He administered an [[Cutter (professional wrestling)#Jumping cutter
column32: RKO]] before then teaming with JBL against him. As Orton was set to punt Triple H's noggin again, however, JBL turned on him and laid him out with a vicious [[Professional wrestling attacks#Clothesline

column2: feud]] heading into Backlash on the SmackDown brand was between [[The Undertaker]] and [[Edge (wrestler)

column4: SmackDown]] after failing to regain the [[WWE Tag Team Championship
column5: Tag Team Championship]] from John Morrison and The Miz, MVP attacked Matt Hardy targeting and injuring his knee. The feud would start again at [[WrestleMania XXIV]] where Matt Hardy cost MVP the Money in the Bank Ladder Match by performing a Twist of Fate at the top of the ladder. Hardy would then face MVP on the April 4th, 2008 edition of SmackDown in a non-title match, which he won. It was confirmed on the next SmackDown that Matt Hardy would face MVP for the [[WWE United States Championship

General Manager Vickie Guerrero booked Kane to defend the ECW Championship against Chavo Guerrero at Backlash.<ref name=\"4/04 SmackDown\"/> The feud intensified on the April 8 episode of ''[[ECW (WWE)
column13: ECW]]'', where during a contract signing for Backlash, Guerrero, with assistance from [[Justin LaRouche

column1: Another feud leading up to Backlash was between [[Shawn Michaels]] and [[Dave Bautista
column2: Batista]]. Upset over the retirement of [[Ric Flair]] at the hands of Michaels at WrestleMania XXIV, Batista interrupted Michaels' address on the April 4 episode of ''SmackDown!'' and called him a \"selfish\" person for what he did at WrestleMania. Batista blamed Michaels for not lying down for Flair and thus protecting his career instead of retiring him. Michaels defended his actions by saying Flair had called upon him to bring his best to WrestleMania, which he did. The conflict continued on an episode of [[Chris Jericho]]'s \"[[WWE Raw#Recurring segments
column3: Highlight Reel]]\" interview segment that featured both men on the April 7 episode of ''Raw''. Following another tense verbal standoff, Batista left the ring saying he had something in store for Michaels. Moments later, Raw General Manager William Regal said he had confirmed a match with SmackDown General Manager Vickie Guerrero between Michaels and Batista at Backlash. In addition, the following week Jericho had a confrontation with Shawn Michaels who ended up kicking Jericho in the face. Frustrated, Jericho went to Regal in an effort to possibly add himself to the match. Regal did indeed add Jericho to the match, but not as a competitor. Instead he announced Jericho as a [[Professional wrestling match types#Special referee
column4: Special Guest Referee]] for the match.

column1: Before the event began and aired [[Live television
column2: live]] on [[pay-per-view]], a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Dark match
column3: dark match]] was featured in which [[WWE Tag Team Championship (2002–2010)
