column26: Torneo Gran Alternativa]]'' (\"Great Alternativa Tournament\") where younger wrestlers team up with established veteran wrestlers. El Cuatrero was paired with [[Rey Bucanero]], but the duo lost to [[Tritón (wrestler)
column28: Místico]] in the first round.<ref name=Medio2016BlockA>{{cite web
column30: title=Rey Escorpión y Fujín, por la Gran Alternativa
column35: trans-title=Rey Escorpión and Fujín go for the Gran Alternativa}}</ref> A year later, El Cuatrero was teamed up with his uncle Máscara Año 2000 for the 2017 version of the ''[[Torneo Gran Alternativa (2017)
column36: Torneo Gran Alternativa]]'',  but like the 2016 tournament, El Cuatrero did not make it past the first round as the team lost to [[Esfinge]] and [[Atlantis (wrestler)
column39: title=CMLL Arena Mexico Results: La Gran Alternativa tournament begins
column44: last=Aiken}}</ref> While El Cuatrero's first years on the main roster had seen little success, July 2017 proved a turning point in how ''Nueva Generacion Dinamitas'' was booked as El Cuatrero and Sansón defeated [[Black Terry]] and [[Negro Navarro]] to win the [[CMLL Arena Coliseo Tag Team Championship]], CMLL's second-highest ranked tag team championship.<ref name=NGD/> Three days later the trio defeated ''[[Los Hijos del Infierno]]'' ([[Ephesto]], [[Luciferno]], and [[Mephisto (wrestler)
column45: Mephisto]]) to win the [[Mexican National Trios Championship]], making Ephesto a triple championship.<ref name=NGDTrios/> The trio would win CMLL's ''La Copa Dinastia'', defeating the trios of Blue Panther, [[Blue Panther Jr.]], [[The Panther (wrestler)

column1: On January 19, 2018, as part of the annual [[Fantastica Mania 2018
column2: 2018 Fantastica Mania]] tour of Japan, El Cuatrero defeated [[Ángel de Oro]] to win the [[CMLL World Middleweight Championship]].<ref name=CuatreroMiddle/> The match and championship change was the beginning of a long-running storyline feud between El Cuatrero and Ángel de Oro, where challenges for a ''Lucha de Apuestas'' match soon followed.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Ángel de Oro y Cuatrero se jugaran las mascaras en Homenaje a Dos Leyendas
column9: trans-title=Ángel de Oro, fighting for the asks at Homage to Two Legends}}</ref> On February 14, 2018, ''Nueva Generacion Dinamitas'' announced they were giving up the CMLL Arena Coliseo Tag Team Championship, with the storyline given that they were focusing on winning the [[CMLL World Tag Team Championship]].<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Sansón y Cuatrero renuncian al Campeonato de Parejas de la Arena Coliseo.
column12: trans-title=Sansón and Cuatrero give up the Arena Colise Tag Team Championship
column17: language=Spanish}}</ref> The storyline feud between El Cuatrero and Ángel de Oro reached its peak at the 2018 ''[[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas (2018)
column18: Homenaje a Dos Leyendas]]'' show, where both competitors put their mask on the line in the main event match of the night. It ended with El Cuatrero defeating Ángel de Oro two falls to one, forcing Ángel de Oro to remove his mask as per ''lucha libre'' tradition.<ref name=AngelApuesta/> He would later make his first and second successful defense of the CMLL World Middleweight Championship against Ángel de Oro.<ref name=CMLLMiddle>{{cite web
column20: title= CMLL World Middleweight Championship >> Title Reigns >> 19.01.2018 - Today: El Cuatrero
column22: work=CageMatch}}</ref> At the [[CMLL 85th Anniversary Show]], the Dinamitas defeated Atlantis, El Soberano Jr., and Mistico as part of CMLL's most important show of the year.<ref>{{cite web
column24: title=CMLL 85. Aniversario live results: hair vs. hair tag team main event
column30: last=Aiken}}</ref> On November 6, 2018, Cuatrero made his third successful middleweight championship defense as he defeated [[Titán (wrestler)

column1: 2019 was the first year that all three members of Nueva Generación Dinamitas participated in the annual [[Fantastica Mania 2019
column2: Fantastica Mania]] tour of Japan, capping off the tour with a successful championship defense against Ángel de Oro, Atlantis, and Titán on the last day of the tour.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=NJPW/CMLL Fantastica Mania results: 'My Dad is a heel wrestler' match
column9: last=Renner}}</ref> 2019 also marked the first year that El Cuatrero participated in the [[CMLL Universal Championship (2019)
column10: Universal Championship]], a tournament where all 16 participants held a championship recognized by CMLL. In the opening round. he defeated perennial rival Soberano Jr. before losing to Último Guerrero in the quarterfinals.<ref name=BlockBOvaciones>{{cite web
column22: title=Niebla Roja se impone en la segunda fase del torneo Campeón Universal 2019
column23: trans-title=Niebla Roja looks imposing in the second phase of the 2019 Universal Championship
column26: language=Spanish}}</ref> For the 2019 ''[[CMLL Torneo Nacional de Parejas Increíbles (2019)
column27: Torneo Nacional de Parejas Increíbles]]'' (\"National incredible teams tournament), Cuatrero was paired up with Místico, as a ''[[Heel (professional wrestling)
column29: tecnico]]'' (the \"Good guy\") team up for the event. The odd couple defeated [[Hechicero]] and [[Stuka Jr.]], then Atlantis and Negro Casas, before ultimately losing to Último Guerrero and Volador Jr. in the semifinals.<ref name=Increibles2019B>{{cite web
column31: title= Último Guerrero y Volador Jr. van a final de \"Torneo increíble\"
column32: trans-title=Último Guerrero and Volador Jr. goes to the finals of the “Incredible Tournament”
column39: title=Volador y Guerrero a la final
column40: trans-title=Volador and Guerrero in the finals
column46: last=Rosas Plata}}</ref> As part of the 66th anniversary of Arena Puebla, NGD successfully defended the Mexican National Trios Championship against ''[[Los Ingobernables]]'' ([[El Terrible]], [[La Bestia del Ring]], and [[Rush (wrestler)
column47: Rush]]), in what was their tenth overall championship defense.<ref>{{cite web
column49: title=Mexican National Trios Championship >> 25.07.2017 - today: La Sangre Dinamita (El Cuatrero, Forasteo & Sanson)
column51: accessdate=March 31, 2020}}</ref> In December, El Cuatrero made his fourth successful defense of the CMLL World Middleweight Championship as he defeated [[Carístico]] on December 12.<ref>{{cite web

column2: Sin Piedad]]'' show offered Cuatrero the opportunity to become a quadruple champion as he and Sansón challenged Místico and Carístico for the CMLL World Tag Team Championship, but lost the match.<ref name=SP2020Medio>{{cite web
column4: title=Cayó la primera máscara en el 2020 dentro del CMLL; Espíritu Negro reveló su rostro
column5: trans-title=The first mask loss in CMLL of 2020; Espiritu Negro revealed his face
column10: Fantastica Mania]] tour, Cuatrero and his brother participated in the [[List of CMLL tag team tournaments#2020 Family tag team tournament
column11: family tag team tournament]], where they ended up defeating ''Los Hermanos Chavez'' (Ángel de Oro and Niebla Roja) in the finals.<ref name=FM20Jan19>{{cite web
column17: work=[[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]]}}</ref> On the final day of the tour, January 20, NGD successfully defended the Mexican National Trios Championship against ''Los Hermanos Chavez'' and Titán.<ref name=NJPWFM202Jan20>{{cite web
column23: language=Japanese}}</ref> On February 24, 2020, El Cuatrero and Sansón won the ''[[#Torneo de parejas familiares
column24: Torneo de parejas familiares]]'' (\"Family team tournament\") as they defeated the uncle/nephew team of Rey Bucanero and [[Drone (wrestler)
column25: Drone]] in the first round, the father/son team of [[Euforia (wrestler)
column26: Euforia]] and Soberano Jr. in the second round, and finally the [[Gran Guerrero]]/Último Guerrero brothers in the finals.<ref name=NGDFamiliares/><ref name=LuchaCentral/>

column1: While working for CMLL, Cuatrero, like all CMLL workes, is allowed to take independent circuit bookings on days he is not needed by CMLL or arranged through CMLL. On February 19, 2017, Cuatrero and Sansón unsuccessfully challenged Black Terry and Negro Navarro for the CMLL Arena Coliseo Tag Team Championship on a ''Lucha Memes'' show in Puebla.<ref>{{cite web
column6: work=CageMatch}}</ref> NGD also successfully defended the Mexican National Tag Team Championship against Los Kamikazes del Aire (Alas de Acero, [[Aramis]], and Iron Kid) at a subsequent ''Lucha Memes'' show.<ref>{{cite web

column1: As part of CMLL's collaboration with [[The Crash Lucha Libre]], Nueva Generación Dinamitas has performed on several The Crash shows over the years. In their initial appearance for The Crash, Nueva Generación Dinamitas lost to [[La Rebelión Amarilla]] ([[Bestia 666]], [[Jacob Fatu]] and [[Mecha Wolf 450]]).<ref>{{cite web
column8: work=TJ Sports}}</ref> The team returned to The Crash for their [[The Crash VII Aniversario
column9: VII Anniversary Show]] show, where they lost to ''Los Lucha Bros'' ([[Pentagón Jr.
column11: The King]]) in a match for [[The Crash Tag Team Championship]] that also included [[Reno Scum]] (Adam Thornstowe and Luster the Legend).<ref name=LuchaCentral>{{cite web
column13: title=¡Resultados Aniversario VII THE CRASH ! Espanol
column14: trans-title=Results of the Crash VII Anniversary! Spanish
column27: work=Lucha World}}</ref> They returned to The Crash in December 2018, losing to Bestia 666 and [[Garza Jr.]] in the main event.<ref>{{cite web
column29: title=Garza Jr. Y Bestia 666 Demostraron Porque Son La Cara De The Crash Lucha Libre
column30: trans-title=Garza Jr. Y Bestia 666 demonstrate why they are the face of The Crash Lucha Libre
column34: date=December 1, 2018}}</ref> In 2019 Cuatrero and Sansón worked an extended storyline against ''[[Los Traumas]]'' ([[Trauma I]] and [[Trauma II]]) in The Crash. In June Sansón was forced to team up with Trauma I to face Cuatrero and Trauma I in a ''[[relevos increíbles]]'' (\"incredible pairs\" match), where the regular partners refused to wrestle against each other. In the end, Sansón and Trauma I after Trauma II hit El Cuatrero during the match.<ref>{{cite web
column39: work=CageMatch}}</ref> This was followed by a tag team match where NGD defeated Los Traumas by disqualification as part of their ongoing storyline.<ref>{{cite web

column1: On June 16, 2019, Cuatrero, Forastero, and Sansón appeared at International Wrestling Revolution Group's annual [[Festival de las Máscaras (2019)
column2: Festival de las Máscaras]] show. The trio defeated their cousin Máscara Año 2000 Jr., teaming with Capo del Sur and Capo del Norte, who both use ring characters inspired by the original ''Los Dinamitas''<ref name=FdM2019>{{cite web
column4: title=Emotivo homenaje a Vampiro Canadiense en el festival de máscaras.
column5: trans-title=Emotional homage to Canadian Vampire at the Festival of the Masks

column3: masked]] [[professional wrestler]] currently working for ''[[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]]'' (CMLL) based in Mexico City. He is the son of ''lucha libre'' legend [[Cien Caras]] and the nephew of [[Máscara Año 2000]] and [[Universo 2000]]. Cuatrero, his brother [[Sansón (wrestler)
column4: Sansón]] and their cousin [[Forastero]] form a trio known as ''Nueva Generación Dinamitas'' (\"New Generation Dynamites\"), the successor to ''[[Los Capos
column5: Los Hermanos Dinamita]]'' (Cien Caras, Máscara Año 2000 and Universo 2000). His real name is not a matter of public record, as is often the case with masked wrestlers in Mexico where their private lives are kept a secret from the wrestling fans.<ref name=Mondo>{{cite book
column7: title= Mondo Lucha Libre: the bizarre & honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling
column10: chapter = Okay... what is Lucha Libre?
column12: isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}}</ref> His [[ring name]] is Spanish for \"The Horse thief\" or  \"The [[Cattle rustler
column13: Rustler]]\", reflected in the cowboy-inspired ring gear and mask he wears during shows.

column1: El Cuatrero is the current [[CMLL World Middleweight Champion]] and at one point held four championships simultaneously, which included the [[CMLL Arena Coliseo Tag Team Championship]] (with Sansón), the [[Mexican National Trios Championship]] (with Sansón and Forastero) and the Occidente Trios Championship (with Sansón and Forastero). He won the mask of [[Ángel de Oro]] in the main event of CMLL's 2018 ''[[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas]]'' show on March 16, 2018.

El Cuatrero was born in 1996, a son of [[professional wrestler]] Carmelo Reyes González, better known under the [[ring name]] [[Cien Caras]] (\"100 Faces\"). His older brother, known under the name [[Sansón (wrestler)
column2: Sansón]] (\"[[Samson]]\") was born in 1994. His uncles Jesús (known as [[Máscara Año 2000]]) and Andrés ([[Universo 2000]]) were also professional wrestlers.<ref name=MondoFamily/> Several of their sons followed their fathers into professional wrestling, including [[Forastero]], [[Universo 2000 Jr.]] and [[Máscara Año 2000 Jr.]]<ref>{{cite web
column4: title= Wagner destapó a Máscara 2000 Jr.
column11: trans-title=Wagner unmasks Máscara 2000 Jr.}}</ref> Initially, Carmelo Reyes did not want his sons to become professional wrestlers, wanting them to get an education instead. He reluctantly agreed that they could train for ''Lucha Libre'' with their uncle Andrés, but only as a hobby. During their training, Carmelo noticed how serious they took it and reluctantly agreed with their choice to become professional wrestlers.<ref name=DivinasLuchas>{{cite web
column13: title=Divinas de la lucha Cuatrero y Sansón

column1: There is a long tradition of wrestlers paying for the right to use a ring name in Mexican wrestling, including being allowed to portray a second or third-generation wrestler without being related to the originator.<ref name=MondoFamily>{{cite book
column3: title=Mondo Lucha a Go Go: the bizarre & honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling
column8: isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}}</ref> It has been confirmed that wrestlers [[Cien Caras Jr.]] and [[El Hijo de Cien Caras]] are unrelated to the Reyes family, while it is unclear if [[Hijo de Máscara Año 2000]] is a blood relative or a purely fictional relative.<ref name=Adios>{{cite web
column10: title=El adiós del Hijo de Cien Caras
column21: trans-title=Goodbye to El Hijo de Cien Caras}}</ref> Reyes later stated that he allowed the \"Cien Caras\" name to be rented by other wrestlers as his sons were very young and might not want to become professional wrestlers.<ref name=MedioIntro/>

column5: Sansón]], El Cuatrero and [[Forastero]] outside the ring in November 2018]]

column1: While the El Cuatrero name was first used in 2014, Sansón stated that they made their in-ring debut around the year 2010 and worked locally in Lagos de Moreno, while finishing school.<ref name=MedioIntro>{{cite web
column3: title=Herederos de Cien Caras cerca de debut en Arena México
column10: trans-title=The successors to Cien Casas make their debut in Arena Mexico}}</ref> In an interview Cuatrero did state that he briefly wrestled as \"Máscara Universal\", but his father did not like it and instead suggested the name \"El Cuatrero\", Spanish for \"The [[Cattle rustler]], inspired by the cowboy gimmick that his father and his uncles had used.<ref name=Starmedia>{{cite web
column12: title=Sansón Y Cuatrero Revivirán Memoria De Cien Caras En La Arena México
column17: trans-title=Sanson and Cuatrero revieve the memory of Cien Caras in Arena Mexico
column28: trans-title=Sanson and Cuatrero, the \"New Dynamites\"}}</ref> During their time working locally in Lagos de Moreno, the duo won their first ''[[Lucha de Apuestas]]'', or bet match, where they defeated Los Centellas (I and II) and unmasked the duo.<ref name=DivinasLuchas/>

column1: The Reyes  brothers worked locally until early 2014, when they began working in Guadalajara for the local ''[[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]]'' (CMLL) promoters in Arena Coliseo. They began training at the CMLL wrestling school, receving training from [[Último Guerrero]], [[Virus (wrestler)
column2: Virus]] and [[Franco Colombo]].<ref name=Starmedia/> The Reyes brothers made their CMLL debut on March 25, 2014, where they, along with Universo 2000 lost to the trio of [[Blue Panther]], [[Sagrado (wrestler)
column10: language=German}}</ref> While working in Guadalajara, El Cuatrero and Sansón competed in a tournament to determine the number one contenders for the local Occidente Tag Team Championship, but the two were eliminated by the team of Flash and Flash II.<ref>{{cite web
column16: language=German}}</ref> The brothers teamed up with Jocker, with the winners being crowned the new Occidente Trios Champions. The team made it all the way to the final match of the tournament but was defeated by Furia Roja, Mr. Trueno, and Ray Trueno.<ref>{{cite web
column22: language=German}}</ref> On November 11, 2015, Cuatrero and Sansón teamed up with their cousin Forastero and won the Occidente Trios Championship.<ref>{{cite web

column1: On January 5, 2017, El Cuatrero worked his first CMLL match in Mexico City in the company's main venue. as he participated in the 2017 version of ''[[La Copa Junior]]'' but was eliminated from the tournament before the finals.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Puma, finalista de la Copa Jr. del CMLL
column8: trans-title=Puma finalist in the CMLL La Copa Jr.}}</ref> At that point, the Reyes brothers began being referred to as ''Nueva Generacion Dinamitas'' (Spanish for \"New Generation Dynamites\"; NGD) as a reference to their heritage. On March 18, 2016, ''Nueva Generacion Dinamitas'' worked their first major show for CMLL, defeating [[Soberano Jr.]] and [[Oro Jr.]] in the opening match of that year's ''[[Homenaje a Dos Leyendas (2016)
column9: Homenaje A Dos Leyendas]]'' show.<ref name=DosLeyendas2016SL>{{cite web

column1: While working for CMLL, Cuatrero, like all CMLL workes, is allowed to take independent circuit bookings on days he is not needed by CMLL or arranged through CMLL. On February 19, 2017, Cuatrero and Sansón unsuccessfully challenged Black Terry and Negro Navarro for the CMLL Arena Coliseo Tag Team Championship on a ''Lucha Memes'' show in Puebla.<ref>{{cite web
column6: work=CageMatch}}</ref> NGD also successfully defended the Mexican National Tag Team Championship against Los Kamikazes del Aire (Alas de Acero, [[Aramis]], and Iron Kid) at a subsequent ''Lucha Memes'' show.<ref>{{cite web

column1: As part of CMLL's collaboration with [[The Crash Lucha Libre]], Nueva Generación Dinamitas has performed on several The Crash shows over the years. In their initial appearance for The Crash, Nueva Generación Dinamitas lost to [[La Rebelión Amarilla]] ([[Bestia 666]], [[Jacob Fatu]] and [[Mecha Wolf 450]]).<ref>{{cite web
column8: work=TJ Sports}}</ref> The team returned to The Crash for their [[The Crash VII Aniversario
column9: VII Anniversary Show]] show, where they lost to ''Los Lucha Bros'' ([[Pentagón Jr.
column11: The King]]) in a match for [[The Crash Tag Team Championship]] that also included [[Reno Scum]] (Adam Thornstowe and Luster the Legend).<ref name=LuchaCentral>{{cite web
column13: title=¡Resultados Aniversario VII THE CRASH ! Espanol
column14: trans-title=Results of the Crash VII Anniversary! Spanish
column27: work=Lucha World}}</ref> They returned to The Crash in December 2018, losing to Bestia 666 and [[Garza Jr.]] in the main event.<ref>{{cite web
column29: title=Garza Jr. Y Bestia 666 Demostraron Porque Son La Cara De The Crash Lucha Libre
column30: trans-title=Garza Jr. Y Bestia 666 demonstrate why they are the face of The Crash Lucha Libre
column34: date=December 1, 2018}}</ref> In 2019 Cuatrero and Sansón worked an extended storyline against ''[[Los Traumas]]'' ([[Trauma I]] and [[Trauma II]]) in The Crash. In June Sansón was forced to team up with Trauma I to face Cuatrero and Trauma I in a ''[[relevos increíbles]]'' (\"incredible pairs\" match), where the regular partners refused to wrestle against each other. In the end, Sansón and Trauma I after Trauma II hit El Cuatrero during the match.<ref>{{cite web
column39: work=CageMatch}}</ref> This was followed by a tag team match where NGD defeated Los Traumas by disqualification as part of their ongoing storyline.<ref>{{cite web

column1: On June 16, 2019, Cuatrero, Forastero, and Sansón appeared at International Wrestling Revolution Group's annual [[Festival de las Máscaras (2019)
column2: Festival de las Máscaras]] show. The trio defeated their cousin Máscara Año 2000 Jr., teaming with Capo del Sur and Capo del Norte, who both use ring characters inspired by the original ''Los Dinamitas''<ref name=FdM2019>{{cite web
column4: title=Emotivo homenaje a Vampiro Canadiense en el festival de máscaras.

column2: Particulate mask that meets the N95 standard of the United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH)}}

column1: An '''N95 mask''' or '''N95 respirator''' is a particulate-filtering facepiece [[respirator]] that meets the N95 standard of the U.S. [[NIOSH air filtration rating
column2: National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) air filtration rating]], meaning that it filters at least 95% of [[airborne particles]], while not resistant to [[oil]] like the P95. It is the most common particulate-filtering facepiece respirator.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=NIOSH-Approved N95 Particulate Filtering Facepiece Respirators - A Suppliers List
column8: website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health
column13: access-date=2020-03-27}}</ref>  It is an example of a [[mechanical filter respirator]], which provides protection against [[particulates]], but not [[gas]]es or [[vapor]]s.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health

column1: N95 respirators are considered functionally equivalent to certain respirators regulated under non-U.S. jurisdictions, such as [[FFP mask
column2: FFP2 respirators]] of the European Union and KN95 respirators of China.  However, slightly different criteria are used to certify their performance, such as the filter efficiency, test agent and flow rate, and permissible [[pressure drop]].<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Comparison of FFP2, KN95, and N95 and Other Filtering Facepiece Respirator Classes

column1: The N95 mask requires a fine mesh of [[synthetic polymer]] fibers, also known as [[nonwoven polypropylene]] fabric,<ref name=VOADeliver/> which is produced through a highly specialized process called [[melt blowing]] that forms the inner filtration layer that filters out hazardous particles.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=COVID-19 Has Caused A Shortage Of Face Masks. But They're Surprisingly Hard To Make

column1: [[File:Three Key Factors Required for a Respirator to be Effective.pdf
column3: Infographic on three key factors required for a respirator to be effective – click to enlarge]]

column1: [[File:Filtering out Confusion - Frequently Asked Questions about Respiratory Protection.pdf
column3: Guidance for performing a user seal check, which is required every time a respirator is put on – click to enlarge]]

column2: Fit testing]] is a critical component to a respiratory protection program whenever workers use tight-fitting respirators. OSHA requires an initial respirator fit test to identify the right model, style, and size respirator for each worker, as well as annual fit tests. Additionally, tight-fitting respirators, including the N95, require a user seal check each time one is put on.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: N95 respirators were originally designed for industrial use in sectors such as [[mining]], [[construction]], and [[Paint
column4: title=From the Industrial to the Medical – Evolution of the N95 Respirator

column1: According to the NIOSH Respirator Selection Logic, respirators with filters in the N, R, and P series are recommended for concentrations of hazardous particulates that are greater than the relevant [[occupational exposure limit]] but less than the [[immediately dangerous to life or health]] level and the manufacturer's maximum use concentration, subject to the respirator having a sufficient [[Respirator assigned protection factors
N series respirators, including the N95 mask, are only effective in the absence of oil particles, such as [[Lubricant
column4: glycerine]].  For substances hazardous to the eyes, a respirator equipped with a full facepiece, helmet, or hood is recommended.  They should not be used during [[firefighting]], in [[oxygen-deficient atmosphere]], or in an unknown atmosphere, as a [[self-contained breathing apparatus]] is recommended instead.  They should not be used with hazardous gases or vapors, for which a [[Cartridge (respirator)
column5: cartridge respirator]] is recommended.<ref name=\":8\">{{Cite web
column11: website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health

column1: Respirators used in healthcare are traditionally a specific variant called a surgical respirator, which is both approved by NIOSH as a respirator and cleared by the [[Food and Drug Administration]] as a medical device similar to a [[surgical mask]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=A Comparison of Surgical Masks, Surgical N95 Respirators, and Industrial N95 Respirators
column12: access-date=2020-04-07}}</ref>  As part of the [[Families First Coronavirus Response Act]], changes were made to liability and certification laws to allow industrial respirators to be used in healthcare settings, in response to shortages of respirators during the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]].<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=Change in U.S. law will make millions more masks available to doctors and nurses, White House says

column1: In the United States, the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] (OSHA) requires healthcare workers who are expected to perform patient activities with those suspected or confirmed to be infected with [[COVID-19]] to wear respiratory protection, such as an N95 respirator.  Unlike a respirator, a [[surgical mask]] does not have an air-tight seal and thus does not protect its wearer against airborne particles such as virus material.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Proper N95 Respirator Use for Respiratory Protection Preparedness

column1: Under serious outbreak conditions in which respirator supplies are severely limited, workers should work with their employer to choose the respirator that fits best, as, even without fit testing, a respirator will provide better protection than a surgical mask or no mask.{{citation needed
column2: date=April 2020}} In this case, best practices include trying different models or sizes to get a good face seal, checking manufacturer training videos and literature on proper donning and doffing, doing a user seal check several times, and checking the fit in a mirror or asking a colleague to look to be sure the respirator is touching the face.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: During crisis situations where there is a shortage of N95 respirators, such as the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]], the U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) has recommended strategies for optimizing their use in healthcare settings.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Strategies for Optimizing the Supply of N95 Respirators: Crisis/Alternate Strategies
column7: website=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column12: access-date=2020-03-28}} {{PD-inline}}</ref>  N95 respirators can be used beyond their manufacturer-designated shelf life, although components such as the straps and nose bridge material may degrade, which can affect the quality of the fit and seal, making it particularly important that the wearer perform the expected seal check.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=Release of Stockpiled N95 Filtering Facepiece Respirators Beyond the Manufacturer-Designated Shelf Life: Considerations for the COVID-19 Response
column18: website=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column23: access-date=2020-03-28}}</ref>  Respirators can be used that are approved under standards used in other countries that are similar to NIOSH-approved N95 respirators, including FFP2 and FFP3 respirators regulated by the [[European Union]].<ref name=\":1\" />  N95 respirators can be reused a limited number of times after being removed, as long as they have not been used during aerosol-generating procedures and are not contaminated with patients' bodily fluids, although this increases the risk of surface contamination with pathogens.  The respirator manufacturer may recommend a maximum number of donnings or uses; if no manufacturer guidance is available, preliminary data suggests limiting to five uses per device to ensure an adequate safety margin.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web
column25: title=Recommended Guidance for Extended Use and Limited Reuse of N95 Filtering Facepiece Respirators in Healthcare Settings
column29: website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health

column1: When it is no longer possible for all healthcare workers to wear N95 respirators when caring for a COVID-19 patient, respirators should be prioritized for workers performing aerosol-generating procedures on symptomatic persons and those within three feet of an unmasked symptomatic person. Under these conditions, masking of symptomatic patients with a [[surgical mask]] and maintaining distance from the patient are particularly important to reduce the risk of transmission.  When no respirators are left, workers who are at higher risk for severe illness may be excluded from caring for patients, and workers who have clinically recovered from COVID-19 may be preferred to care for patients.  Portable fans with [[HEPA]] filters may also be used to increase ventilation in isolation rooms when surgical masks are being used in place of respirators.  If neither respirators nor surgical masks are available, as a last resort, it may be necessary for healthcare workers to use masks that have never been evaluated or approved by NIOSH or homemade masks, such as [[Cloth facemask
column2: cloth facemasks]], though caution should be exercised when considering this option.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: Given that the global supply of [[personal protective equipment]] (PPE) is insufficient during the pandemic, the [[World Health Organization]] recommends minimizing the need for PPE through [[telemedicine]], physical barriers such as clear windows, allowing only those involved in direct care to enter a room with a COVID-19 patient, using only the PPE necessary for the specific task, continuing use of the same respirator without removing it while caring for multiple patients with the same diagnosis, monitoring and coordinating the PPE [[supply chain]], and discouraging the use of masks for asymptomatic individuals.<ref name=\":32\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Rational use of personal protective equipment for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)

column1: There have been efforts to evaluate cleaning methods for respirators in emergency shortages, although there is concern that this may reduce filter performance, or affect mask fit by deforming the mask.<ref>{{Cite journal
column11: title=Evaluation of Five Decontamination Methods for Filtering Facepiece Respirators
column31: title=Doctors scramble for best practices on reusing medical masks during shortage
column36: access-date=2020-03-27}}</ref>  [[Duke University]] researchers have published a method for cleaning N95 respirators without damaging them using vaporized [[hydrogen peroxide]] to allow reuse for a limited number of times.<ref>{{Cite web
column38: title=Decontamination and Reuse of N95 Respirators with Hydrogen Peroxide Vapor to Address Worldwide Personal Protective Equipment Shortages During the SARS‐CoV‐2 (COVID‐19) Pandemic
column39: authors=Antony Schwartz, Matthew Stiegel, Nicole Greeson, Andrea Vogel, Wayne Thomann, Monte Brown, Gregory D. Sempowski, Thomas Scott Alderman, James Patrick Condreay, James Burch, Cameron Wolfe, Becky Smith, and Sarah Lewis
column49: title=Duke researchers are decontaminating N95 masks so doctors can reuse them to treat coronavirus patients
column55: title=Duke Researchers Find Way to Decontaminate and Reuse N95 Masks, Possibly Alleviating Critical Shortfall
column62: Battelle]] received an [[Emergency Use Authorization]] from the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] to sterilize N95 masks.<ref>{{Cite web
column64: title=FDA lifts restrictions on Ohio-based Battelle's mask-sterilizing technology amid coronavirus shortages
column75: title=COVID-19: Deploying a Critical New PPE Decontamination System
column84: access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref>  OSHA does not currently have any standards for disinfecting N95 masks.<ref name=\":4\" />  NIOSH recommends that during shortages N95 respirators may be used up to five times without cleaning them, as long as [[aerosol]]-generating procedures are not performed, and respirators are not contaminated with patients' [[Body fluid
column85: bodily fluids]].  Contamination can be reduced by wearing a cleanable [[face shield]] over an N95 respirator, as well as using clean [[Medical glove
column86: gloves]] when donning and seal-checking a used N95 respirator and discarding the gloves immediately after.<ref name=\":5\" />

column2: alt=A table listing the attributes of surgical masks and N95 respirators in eight categories
column4: An infographic on the difference between [[Surgical mask
column5: surgical masks]] and [[NIOSH air filtration rating

column1: A [[surgical mask]] is a loose-fitting, disposable device that creates a physical barrier between the mouth and nose of the wearer and potential contaminants in the immediate environment. If worn properly, a surgical mask is meant to help block large-particle [[Respiratory droplets
column2: droplets]], splashes, sprays, or splatter that may contain viruses and bacteria. Surgical masks may also help reduce exposure of the wearer's saliva and respiratory secretions to others.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web
column4: title=N95 Respirators and Surgical Masks (Face Masks)

column1: A surgical mask, by design, does not filter or block very small particles in the air that may be transmitted by coughs, sneezes, or certain medical procedures. Surgical masks also do not provide complete protection from germs and other contaminants because of the loose fit between the surface of the face mask and the face.<ref name=\":2\" />  Collection efficiency of surgical mask filters can range from less than 10% to nearly 90% for different manufacturers’ masks when measured using the test parameters for NIOSH certification.  However, a study found that even for surgical masks with \"good\" filters, 80–100% of subjects failed an OSHA-accepted qualitative fit test, and a quantitative test showed 12–25% leakage.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web

The U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] recommends surgical masks in procedures where there can be an aerosol generation from the wearer, if small aerosols can produce a disease to the patient.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: website=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column12: access-date=February 9, 2020}}</ref>  The CDC recommends the use of respirators with at least N95 certification to protect the wearer from inhalation of infectious particles including [[Mycobacterium tuberculosis]], [[Avian influenza]], [[severe acute respiratory syndrome]] (SARS), [[Influenza pandemic
column18: title=2007 Guideline for Isolation Precautions: Preventing Transmission of Infectious Agents in Healthcare Settings
column19: publisher=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column25: url-status=live}}</ref> Some N95 respirators have been also cleared by the [[Food and Drug Administration
column26: U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] as ''surgical'' are labeled \"''Surgical N95''\", and provide respiratory protection ''to the'' ''wearer as well''.<ref>{{cite web
column28: title=Respirator Trusted-Source Information: Ancillary Respirator Information
column32: website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health

column1: N95 facemasks have several historical predecessors.  One was a design for a [[cloth facemask]] by [[Lien-teh Wu]], who was working for the Chinese Imperial Court in the fall of 1910 during a [[Bubonic plague]] outbreak.  It was the first that protected users from bacteria in empirical testing, and inspired masks used during the [[1918 flu pandemic]].<ref name=\":62\">{{Cite web
column3: title=The untold origin story of the N95 mask
column10: gas masks]] developed during [[World War I]], which were adapted for use by miners. They were reusable but bulky and uncomfortable due to their [[fiberglass]] filters and heavy rubber construction.<ref name=\":7\" /><ref name=\":62\" />

column1: In the 1970s, the [[United States Bureau of Mines
column2: Bureau of Mines]] and NIOSH developed standards for single-use respirators, and the first N95 respirator was developed by [[3M]] and approved in 1972.<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite web
column4: title=The untold origin story of the N95 mask
column10: access-date=2020-03-27}}</ref>  3M used a [[melt blowing]] process that it had developed decades prior and used in products such as premade [[ribbon]] bows and [[bra]] cups; its use in a wide array of products had been pioneered by designer [[Sara Little Turnbull]].<ref>{{Cite web
column22: access-date=2020-04-01}}</ref>  While designed for industrial use, they were increasingly used in healthcare settings in the 1990s, originally to prevent the spread of drug-resistant [[tuberculosis]].<ref name=\":7\" /><ref name=\":62\" /> Many American companies stopped producing N95 masks in the 2000s due to litigation costs and foreign competition.<ref>{{Cite web
column26: title= Six Respirator Manufacturers Warn President of Shortage of Masks

column2: Face masks during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic}}

column1: The masks were in short supply and high demand during the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Feds have 1.5 million expired N95 masks in storage despite CDC clearing them for use on COVID-19: report
column7: website=TheHill}}</ref> Production of N95 masks was limited due to constraints on the supply of [[nonwoven polypropylene]] fabric (which is used as the primary filter) as well as the cessation of exports from China.<ref name=VOADeliver>{{Cite news
column11: title= World Depends on China for Face Masks But Can Country Deliver?
column21: title= Critical Component of Protective Masks in Short Supply - The epidemic has driven up demand for material in N95 filters; 'everyone thinks there is this magic factory somewhere'
column25: accessdate=}}</ref> China controls 50% of global production of masks, and facing its own coronavirus epidemic, dedicated all its production for domestic use, only allowing exports through government-allocated humanitarian assistance.<ref name=VOADeliver/>

column1: In March 2020, President [[Donald Trump]] applied the [[Defense Production Act]] against the American company [[3M]] which allows the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] to obtain as many N95 respirators as it needs from [[3M]].<ref name=Fabian>{{cite web
column3: title=Trump Attacks 3M Over Mask Production, Drawing Company Pushback
column19: newspaper=[[Washington Post]]}}</ref> White House trade adviser [[Peter Navarro]] stated that there were concerns that 3M products were not making their way to the US.<ref name=Fabian/> 3M replied that it has not changed the prices it charges and is unable to control the prices its dealers or retailers charge.<ref name=Fabian/>

column1: In early April 2020, Berlin politician [[Andreas Geisel]] alleged that a shipment of 200,000 N95 masks that it had ordered from American producer [[3M]]'s China facility were intercepted in [[Bangkok]] and diverted to the United States.<ref name=Betschka>{{cite news
column11: Michael Müller]] blamed president Trump for the confiscation and [[Berlin Police
column13: Barbara Slowik]] stated that she believes \"this is related to the US government's export ban.\"<ref name=Betschka/> 3M said they had no knowledge of the shipment, stating \"We know nothing of an order from the Berlin police for 3M masks that come from China\" and the US government denied that any confiscation had happened and that they use appropriate channels for all its purchases.<ref name=Betschka/><ref>{{Cite news
column17: title=Schutzmasken konfisziert?  Schwere Vorwürfe aus Berlin: Jetzt reagiert das Weiße Haus
column21: accessdate=}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' also reported that \"There is no solid proof Trump [nor any other American official] approved the [German] heist\".<ref>{{cite news
column23: title=US's global reputation hits rock-bottom over Trump's coronavirus response

column1: [[Jared Moskowitz]], head of the [[Florida Division of Emergency Management]], accused 3M of selling N95 masks directly to foreign countries for cash instead of the United States. Moskowitz stated that 3M agreed to authorized distributors and brokers to represent they were selling the masks to [[Florida]], but instead his team for the last several weeks \"get to warehouses that are completely empty.\" He then said the 3M authorized U.S. distributors later told him the masks Florida contracted for never showed up because the company instead prioritized orders that came in later, for higher prices, from foreign countries (including Germany, Russia, and France). As a result, Moskowitz highlighted the issue on Twitter, saying he decided to “troll” 3M.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Florida emergency management official says 3M selling masks to foreign countries: 'We're chasing ghosts'
column10: title=Interview With Jared Moskowitz, Director of Florida's Division of Emergency Management
column15: title=Florida emergency management chief says state will have enough ICU beds and ventilators
column20: accessdate=5 April 2020}}</ref> ''[[Forbes]]'' reported that \"roughly 280 million masks from warehouses around the U.S. had been purchased by foreign buyers [on March 30, 2020] and were earmarked to leave the country, according to the broker — and that was in ''one'' day\", causing massive critical shortages of masks in the U.S.<ref>{{Cite news
column22: title=I Spent A Day In The Coronavirus-Driven Feeding Frenzy Of N95 Mask Sellers And Buyers And This Is What I Learned
column29: title=Pence task force freezes coronavirus aid amid backlash
column31: authors=Natasha Bertrand, Gabby Orr, Daneil Lippman and Nahal Toosi

column1: As more and more countries restricted the export of N95 masks, Novo Textiles in [[British Columbia]] had plans to become the number-one manufacturer in [[Canada]] <ref>{{cite web
column2: title=COVID-19: Coquitlam company retools, will be first in Canada to produce N95 respirators
column7: publication-date=}}</ref>.  AMD Medicom in [[Quebec]] also plans to become the second Canadian manufacturer of N95 masks, with a contract to supply the [[Government of Canada]] <ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Medicom to begin manufacturing N95 masks in Canada as foreign countries curb exports

column2: Particulate mask that meets the N95 standard of the United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH)}}

column1: In the United States, the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] (OSHA) requires healthcare workers who are expected to perform patient activities with those suspected or confirmed to be infected with [[COVID-19]] to wear respiratory protection, such as an N95 respirator.  Unlike a respirator, a [[surgical mask]] does not have an air-tight seal and thus does not protect its wearer against airborne particles such as virus material.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Proper N95 Respirator Use for Respiratory Protection Preparedness

column1: Under serious outbreak conditions in which respirator supplies are severely limited, workers should work with their employer to choose the respirator that fits best, as, even without fit testing, a respirator will provide better protection than a surgical mask or no mask.{{citation needed
column2: date=April 2020}} In this case, best practices include trying different models or sizes to get a good face seal, checking manufacturer training videos and literature on proper donning and doffing, doing a user seal check several times, and checking the fit in a mirror or asking a colleague to look to be sure the respirator is touching the face.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: During crisis situations where there is a shortage of N95 respirators, such as the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]], the U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) has recommended strategies for optimizing their use in healthcare settings.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Strategies for Optimizing the Supply of N95 Respirators: Crisis/Alternate Strategies
column7: website=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column12: access-date=2020-03-28}} {{PD-inline}}</ref>  N95 respirators can be used beyond their manufacturer-designated shelf life, although components such as the straps and nose bridge material may degrade, which can affect the quality of the fit and seal, making it particularly important that the wearer perform the expected seal check.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=Release of Stockpiled N95 Filtering Facepiece Respirators Beyond the Manufacturer-Designated Shelf Life: Considerations for the COVID-19 Response
column18: website=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column23: access-date=2020-03-28}}</ref>  Respirators can be used that are approved under standards used in other countries that are similar to NIOSH-approved N95 respirators, including FFP2 and FFP3 respirators regulated by the [[European Union]].<ref name=\":1\" />  N95 respirators can be reused a limited number of times after being removed, as long as they have not been used during aerosol-generating procedures and are not contaminated with patients' bodily fluids, although this increases the risk of surface contamination with pathogens.  The respirator manufacturer may recommend a maximum number of donnings or uses; if no manufacturer guidance is available, preliminary data suggests limiting to five uses per device to ensure an adequate safety margin.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web
column25: title=Recommended Guidance for Extended Use and Limited Reuse of N95 Filtering Facepiece Respirators in Healthcare Settings
column29: website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health

column1: When it is no longer possible for all healthcare workers to wear N95 respirators when caring for a COVID-19 patient, respirators should be prioritized for workers performing aerosol-generating procedures on symptomatic persons and those within three feet of an unmasked symptomatic person. Under these conditions, masking of symptomatic patients with a [[surgical mask]] and maintaining distance from the patient are particularly important to reduce the risk of transmission.  When no respirators are left, workers who are at higher risk for severe illness may be excluded from caring for patients, and workers who have clinically recovered from COVID-19 may be preferred to care for patients.  Portable fans with [[HEPA]] filters may also be used to increase ventilation in isolation rooms when surgical masks are being used in place of respirators.  If neither respirators nor surgical masks are available, as a last resort, it may be necessary for healthcare workers to use masks that have never been evaluated or approved by NIOSH or homemade masks, such as [[Cloth facemask
column2: cloth facemasks]], though caution should be exercised when considering this option.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: Given that the global supply of [[personal protective equipment]] (PPE) is insufficient during the pandemic, the [[World Health Organization]] recommends minimizing the need for PPE through [[telemedicine]], physical barriers such as clear windows, allowing only those involved in direct care to enter a room with a COVID-19 patient, using only the PPE necessary for the specific task, continuing use of the same respirator without removing it while caring for multiple patients with the same diagnosis, monitoring and coordinating the PPE [[supply chain]], and discouraging the use of masks for asymptomatic individuals.<ref name=\":32\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Rational use of personal protective equipment for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)

column1: There have been efforts to evaluate cleaning methods for respirators in emergency shortages, although there is concern that this may reduce filter performance, or affect mask fit by deforming the mask.<ref>{{Cite journal
column11: title=Evaluation of Five Decontamination Methods for Filtering Facepiece Respirators
column31: title=Doctors scramble for best practices on reusing medical masks during shortage
column36: access-date=2020-03-27}}</ref>  [[Duke University]] researchers have published a method for cleaning N95 respirators without damaging them using vaporized [[hydrogen peroxide]] to allow reuse for a limited number of times.<ref>{{Cite web
column38: title=Decontamination and Reuse of N95 Respirators with Hydrogen Peroxide Vapor to Address Worldwide Personal Protective Equipment Shortages During the SARS‐CoV‐2 (COVID‐19) Pandemic
column39: authors=Antony Schwartz, Matthew Stiegel, Nicole Greeson, Andrea Vogel, Wayne Thomann, Monte Brown, Gregory D. Sempowski, Thomas Scott Alderman, James Patrick Condreay, James Burch, Cameron Wolfe, Becky Smith, and Sarah Lewis
column49: title=Duke researchers are decontaminating N95 masks so doctors can reuse them to treat coronavirus patients
column55: title=Duke Researchers Find Way to Decontaminate and Reuse N95 Masks, Possibly Alleviating Critical Shortfall
column62: Battelle]] received an [[Emergency Use Authorization]] from the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] to sterilize N95 masks.<ref>{{Cite web
column64: title=FDA lifts restrictions on Ohio-based Battelle's mask-sterilizing technology amid coronavirus shortages
column75: title=COVID-19: Deploying a Critical New PPE Decontamination System
column84: access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref>  OSHA does not currently have any standards for disinfecting N95 masks.<ref name=\":4\" />  NIOSH recommends that during shortages N95 respirators may be used up to five times without cleaning them, as long as [[aerosol]]-generating procedures are not performed, and respirators are not contaminated with patients' [[Body fluid
column85: bodily fluids]].  Contamination can be reduced by wearing a cleanable [[face shield]] over an N95 respirator, as well as using clean [[Medical glove
column86: gloves]] when donning and seal-checking a used N95 respirator and discarding the gloves immediately after.<ref name=\":5\" />

column2: alt=A table listing the attributes of surgical masks and N95 respirators in eight categories
column4: An infographic on the difference between [[Surgical mask
column5: surgical masks]] and [[NIOSH air filtration rating

column1: A [[surgical mask]] is a loose-fitting, disposable device that creates a physical barrier between the mouth and nose of the wearer and potential contaminants in the immediate environment. If worn properly, a surgical mask is meant to help block large-particle [[Respiratory droplets
column2: droplets]], splashes, sprays, or splatter that may contain viruses and bacteria. Surgical masks may also help reduce exposure of the wearer's saliva and respiratory secretions to others.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web
column4: title=N95 Respirators and Surgical Masks (Face Masks)

column1: A surgical mask, by design, does not filter or block very small particles in the air that may be transmitted by coughs, sneezes, or certain medical procedures. Surgical masks also do not provide complete protection from germs and other contaminants because of the loose fit between the surface of the face mask and the face.<ref name=\":2\" />  Collection efficiency of surgical mask filters can range from less than 10% to nearly 90% for different manufacturers’ masks when measured using the test parameters for NIOSH certification.  However, a study found that even for surgical masks with \"good\" filters, 80–100% of subjects failed an OSHA-accepted qualitative fit test, and a quantitative test showed 12–25% leakage.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web

The U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] recommends surgical masks in procedures where there can be an aerosol generation from the wearer, if small aerosols can produce a disease to the patient.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: website=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column12: access-date=February 9, 2020}}</ref>  The CDC recommends the use of respirators with at least N95 certification to protect the wearer from inhalation of infectious particles including [[Mycobacterium tuberculosis]], [[Avian influenza]], [[severe acute respiratory syndrome]] (SARS), [[Influenza pandemic
column18: title=2007 Guideline for Isolation Precautions: Preventing Transmission of Infectious Agents in Healthcare Settings
column19: publisher=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column25: url-status=live}}</ref> Some N95 respirators have been also cleared by the [[Food and Drug Administration
column26: U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] as ''surgical'' are labeled \"''Surgical N95''\", and provide respiratory protection ''to the'' ''wearer as well''.<ref>{{cite web
column28: title=Respirator Trusted-Source Information: Ancillary Respirator Information
column32: website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health

column1: N95 facemasks have several historical predecessors.  One was a design for a [[cloth facemask]] by [[Lien-teh Wu]], who was working for the Chinese Imperial Court in the fall of 1910 during a [[Bubonic plague]] outbreak.  It was the first that protected users from bacteria in empirical testing, and inspired masks used during the [[1918 flu pandemic]].<ref name=\":62\">{{Cite web
column3: title=The untold origin story of the N95 mask
column10: gas masks]] developed during [[World War I]], which were adapted for use by miners. They were reusable but bulky and uncomfortable due to their [[fiberglass]] filters and heavy rubber construction.<ref name=\":7\" /><ref name=\":62\" />

column1: In the 1970s, the [[United States Bureau of Mines
column2: Bureau of Mines]] and NIOSH developed standards for single-use respirators, and the first N95 respirator was developed by [[3M]] and approved in 1972.<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite web
column4: title=The untold origin story of the N95 mask
column10: access-date=2020-03-27}}</ref>  3M used a [[melt blowing]] process that it had developed decades prior and used in products such as premade [[ribbon]] bows and [[bra]] cups; its use in a wide array of products had been pioneered by designer [[Sara Little Turnbull]].<ref>{{Cite web
column22: access-date=2020-04-01}}</ref>  While designed for industrial use, they were increasingly used in healthcare settings in the 1990s, originally to prevent the spread of drug-resistant [[tuberculosis]].<ref name=\":7\" /><ref name=\":62\" /> Many American companies stopped producing N95 masks in the 2000s due to litigation costs and foreign competition.<ref>{{Cite web
column26: title= Six Respirator Manufacturers Warn President of Shortage of Masks

column2: Face masks during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]]

column1: The masks were in short supply and high demand during the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Feds have 1.5 million expired N95 masks in storage despite CDC clearing them for use on COVID-19: report
column7: website=TheHill}}</ref> Production of N95 masks was limited due to constraints on the supply of [[nonwoven polypropylene]] fabric (which is used as the primary filter) as well as the cessation of exports from China.<ref name=VOADeliver>{{Cite news
column11: title= World Depends on China for Face Masks But Can Country Deliver?
column21: title= Critical Component of Protective Masks in Short Supply - The epidemic has driven up demand for material in N95 filters; 'everyone thinks there is this magic factory somewhere'
column25: accessdate=}}</ref> China controls 50% of global production of masks, and facing its own coronavirus epidemic, dedicated all its production for domestic use, only allowing exports through government-allocated humanitarian assistance.<ref name=VOADeliver/>

column1: In March 2020, President [[Donald Trump]] applied the [[Defense Production Act]] against the American company [[3M]] which allows the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] to obtain as many N95 respirators as it needs from [[3M]].<ref name=Fabian>{{cite web
column3: title=Trump Attacks 3M Over Mask Production, Drawing Company Pushback
column19: newspaper=[[Washington Post]]}}</ref> White House trade adviser [[Peter Navarro]] stated that there were concerns that 3M products were not making their way to the US.<ref name=Fabian/> 3M replied that it has not changed the prices it charges and is unable to control the prices its dealers or retailers charge.<ref name=Fabian/>

column1: In early April 2020, Berlin politician [[Andreas Geisel]] alleged that a shipment of 200,000 N95 masks that it had ordered from American producer [[3M]]'s China facility were intercepted in [[Bangkok]] and diverted to the United States.<ref name=Betschka>{{cite news
column11: Michael Müller]] blamed president Trump for the confiscation and [[Berlin Police
column13: Barbara Slowik]] stated that she believes \"this is related to the US government's export ban.\"<ref name=Betschka/> 3M said they had no knowledge of the shipment, stating \"We know nothing of an order from the Berlin police for 3M masks that come from China\" and the US government denied that any confiscation had happened and that they use appropriate channels for all its purchases.<ref name=Betschka/><ref>{{Cite news
column17: title=Schutzmasken konfisziert?  Schwere Vorwürfe aus Berlin: Jetzt reagiert das Weiße Haus
column21: accessdate=}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' also reported that \"There is no solid proof Trump [nor any other American official] approved the [German] heist\".<ref>{{cite news
column23: title=US's global reputation hits rock-bottom over Trump's coronavirus response

column1: [[Jared Moskowitz]], head of the [[Florida Division of Emergency Management]], accused 3M of selling N95 masks directly to foreign countries for cash instead of the United States. Moskowitz stated that 3M agreed to authorized distributors and brokers to represent they were selling the masks to [[Florida]], but instead his team for the last several weeks \"get to warehouses that are completely empty.\" He then said the 3M authorized U.S. distributors later told him the masks Florida contracted for never showed up because the company instead prioritized orders that came in later, for higher prices, from foreign countries (including Germany, Russia, and France). As a result, Moskowitz highlighted the issue on Twitter, saying he decided to “troll” 3M.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Florida emergency management official says 3M selling masks to foreign countries: 'We're chasing ghosts'
column10: title=Interview With Jared Moskowitz, Director of Florida's Division of Emergency Management
column15: title=Florida emergency management chief says state will have enough ICU beds and ventilators
column20: accessdate=5 April 2020}}</ref> ''[[Forbes]]'' reported that \"roughly 280 million masks from warehouses around the U.S. had been purchased by foreign buyers [on March 30, 2020] and were earmarked to leave the country, according to the broker — and that was in ''one'' day\", causing massive critical shortages of masks in the U.S.<ref>{{Cite news
column22: title=I Spent A Day In The Coronavirus-Driven Feeding Frenzy Of N95 Mask Sellers And Buyers And This Is What I Learned
column29: title=Pence task force freezes coronavirus aid amid backlash
column31: authors=Natasha Bertrand, Gabby Orr, Daneil Lippman and Nahal Toosi

column1: As more and more countries restricted the export of N95 masks, Novo Textiles in [[British Columbia]] had plans to become the number-one manufacturer in [[Canada]] <ref>{{cite web
column2: title=COVID-19: Coquitlam company retools, will be first in Canada to produce N95 respirators
column7: publication-date=}}</ref>.  AMD Medicom in [[Quebec]] also plans to become the second Canadian manufacturer of N95 masks, with a contract to supply the [[Government of Canada]] <ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Medicom to begin manufacturing N95 masks in Canada as foreign countries curb exports

column1: →‎Application process:correction,safe,Myxsoma,"The '''Paycheck Protection Program''' ('''PPP''') is a $349-billion business loan program established by the [[Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act]] (CARES Act) to help small businesses keep paying their workers. The Paycheck Protection Program allows small businesses to apply for low-interest private loans to pay for their payroll and certain other costs. A PPP loan is approximately equal to 2.5 times the business' average monthly payroll costs. The loan proceeds may be used to cover the business' payroll costs, rent, interest, and utilities for eight weeks. The loan principle may partially or fully forgiven if the business keeps its employee counts and employee wages stable. The program is overseen by the [[United States Small Business Administration
The purpose of the Paycheck Protection Program and loan forgiveness are to provide economic relief to small businesses that have been adversely impacted by the [[Coronavirus disease 2019
column2: COVID-19]] [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in the United States
column6: title= Proclamation on Declaring a National Emergency Concerning the Novel Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Outbreak
column19: title= The Paycheck Protection Program in Action: Questions About Loan Application Risks

column1: In order to be eligible for the Paycheck Protection Program, an applicant must be a small business, [[sole proprietor]], [[independent contractor]], [[self-employment
column3: In the case of a church, a temple, a mosque, a synagogue, another house of worship, an integrated auxiliary of churches, or a convention or association of churches that is not required to apply for a determination of its 501(c)(3) status, the organization is eligible as long as it meets the requirements of Section 501(c)(3) and all other PPP requirements.{{refn
column19: title= Publication 3386: Tax Guide for Veterans' Organizations
column21: date= April 2018 }} }} or a tribal business.{{efn
column22: An tribal business is a business that is wholly owned by one or more [[Tribal sovereignty in the United States
column23: Indian tribal government]]s or by a corporation that is wholly owned by one or more Indian tribal governments. Being partially owned by one or more Indian tribal governments also qualifies if all other owners of the business are either United States citizens or small businesses.{{refn
column32: title= Paycheck Protection Program Loans: Basics for Small Businesses, Sole Proprietorships

column1: Applicants who operate as a sole proprietorship, an independent contractor, or an eligible self-employed individual must have been in operation on February 15, 2020. Other types of applicants must have been in operation on February 15, 2020,{{efn
column2: A seasonal business is eligible to apply for a PPP loan if it was in operation on February 15, 2020, or it was in operation for at least an eight-week period between February 15, 2019, and June 30, 2019.{{refn
column3: name= guidance}} }} and must have either had paid employees or paid independent contractors.{{refn

column2: According to the Small Business Administration, affiliation is generally determined based on ownership, management, interest, and other circumstances.{{refn
column9: title= Updated Business Affiliation Rules: Key Information for Paycheck Protection Program Borrowers
column10: work= National Law Review }} }} Two entities are affiliates if one entity owns at least 50 percent of the other. Two entities are also affiliates of each other if one controls, or has the power to control, the other. Two entities are also affiliates of each other if another entity controls, or has the power to control, them both. Having the power to control does not necessarily imply that the power is actually exercised. If an external party has at least 50 percent ownership, it has the power to control. The power to control may also exist by way of contractual agreement.{{refn
column19: A [[faith-based organization]] may disregard the number of employees of its affiliates if the connection between the two organizations is based on a [[religion
column20: religious teaching]], [[religious belief]], or is otherwise a part of the [[worship
column21: exercise of religion]]. The affiliation rules do apply, however, if the affiliation is solely for non-religious reasons, such as administrative convenience. The application should include a written statement explaining the reason the applicant believes it qualifies for the affiliation exception.{{refn
column25: title= Frequently Asked Questions Regarding Participation of Faith-based Organizations in the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) and the Economic Injury Disaster Loan Program (EIDL)
column28: Affiliation rules are waived for businesses in the hotel and food services industries, franchises in the Small Business Administration's Franchise Directory, and businesses that receive financial assistance from small business investment companies licensed by the Small Business Administration.{{refn

column1: * Have 500 or fewer employees whose primary residence is in the United States;{{efn
column2: Count all employees regardless of work location, as long as their primary place of residence is in the United States. A business that is in either the [[hotel
column3: accommodation]] or [[food service]]s industries and has more than one physical location, however, qualifies if it employs fewer than 500 per location.{{refn

column1: * Meet the [[United States Small Business Administration
column2: Small Business Administration]]'s industry size standards based on [[employee
column4: Number of employees is determined by counting all paid employees, whether employed on a full-time, part-time, or seasonal basis; leased from a [[employment agency
column5: temporary employee agency]] or a [[professional employer organization]]. Count all paid employees as whole employees.{{refn
column9: 121.106b}}(b)}} Volunteers who receive no pay for their services are excluded from the number of employees. }}{{efn
column10: The average number of employees is equal to the average of the number of employees for each payroll between January 1, 2019, and December 31, 2019.{{refn
column11: name=121-106a}} If the applicant began its operations after January 1, 2019, it averages the number of employees in each pay period that it operated between January 1, 2019, and December 31, 2019. }}{{efn
column12: Small business revenue standards are not used for qualification of PPP loans.{{refn
column19: title= Treasury Guidance Clarifies Key Paycheck Protection Program Questions
column29: title= Table of Small Business Size Standards Matched to North American Industry Classification System Codes

column4: total asset]]s, less [[intangible asset]], less [[Liability (financial accounting)
column12: work= Investopedia }} }} }} that did not exceed $15{{nbsp}}million on March 27, 2020, and an average [[net income]] that did not exceed $5{{nbsp}}million for the two full fiscal years prior the date of the PPP application.{{refn

column1: The applicant must be located in the United States or its [[United States possessions
column2: possessions]]. The applicant's primary operations must be located in the United States or its possessions or, alternatively, the applicant's business must make a significant contribution to the [[economy of the United States]].{{refn

column1: An applicant is ''ineligible'' for a PPP loan if:
* It engaged in any activity that is illegal under federal, state, or local law;{{efn
column2: Such as selling [[Medical cannabis in the United States

column1: * It is a household employer, such as an individual employing [[nanny

column9: title= Sen. Cramer Urges SBA to Include Small Tribal Gaming Enterprises in Payment Protection Program
title= Apartment Industry Urges SBA, Treasury to Close Paycheck Protection Loophole

column1: * An owner of 20 percent or more of the business is [[incarceration
column2: incarcerated]], on [[probation]], on [[parole]]; presently subject to an [[indictment]], criminal information, [[arraignment]], or other means by which formal criminal charges are brought in any jurisdiction; or has been convicted of a [[felony]] within the last five years;{{refn

column1: * The applicant, the business' owners, or any business owned or controlled by the applicant or the business' owners has ever obtained a direct or guaranteed loan from any federal agency that is currently delinquent or has [[Default (finance)
column2: default]]ed within the last seven years and caused a loss to the federal government;{{refn

column1: * The business is owned in whole or in part by an [[illegal immigration in the United States
An applicant is not required to demonstrate that it cannot find credit elsewhere.{{refn
Each business may receive only one PPP loan.{{refn
The amount of the PPP loan is based on the applicant's payroll costs.{{refn
column5: title= Business Loan Program Temporary Changes: Paycheck Protection Program: Interim Final Rule

column1: Payroll costs include salaries, wages, commissions, cash tips, paid leave,{{efn
column2: Payroll costs exclude Emergency Paid Sick Leave and Emergency Paid Family Leave under the [[Families First Coronavirus Response Act]].}} severance pay, [[clergy housing allowance
column3: clergy parsonage and housing allowance]], and other compensation paid to employees. These costs are limited to $100,000 annualized per employee. Payroll costs also include group health benefits and insurance and retirement benefits. Payroll costs include taxes withheld from employees' wages and all state and local taxes assessed on compensation, but payroll costs do not include the employer's portion of social security tax, the employer's portion of Medicare tax, and federal unemployment tax.{{refn

column1: Payroll costs do not include payments to workers whose primary residence is outside the United States.{{efn
column3: U.S. permanent resident]]s count as having their primary residence in the United States. Workers with a [[Immigration policy of the United States
column6: H-2A]], do not count as having their primary residence in the United States.{{refn
column10: title= Top 4 FAQs About the Paycheck Protection Program
column12: name= basics}} Payroll costs also do not include payments to non-employees of the applicant. Applicants who are sole proprietors, independent contractors, and self-employed individuals, however, may include their own self-employment earnings from the business, up to $100,000 annualized.{{refn

column1: In order to calculate the amount of the PPP loan, the applicant calculates its payroll costs between January 1, 2019, and December 31, 2019.{{efn
column2: Alternatively, an applicant may use its payroll costs for the previous 12 calendar months instead.Seasonal businesses may use period from February 15, 2019, to June 30, 2019. Businesses not in business on February 15, 2019, may use the period from January 1, 2020, to February 29, 2020.{{refn
column9: title= New Paycheck Protection Loan Guidance for Businesses and Lenders
column10: work= National Law Review }} }} }} Average monthly payroll costs are calculated by dividing this amount divided by 12.{{refn

column1: The PPP loan amount is equal to 2.5 times the average monthly payroll costs. For applicants with an Economic Injury Disaster Loan (EIDL) made between January 31, 2020, and April 3, 2020, the PPP loan amount may be increased by the outstanding amount of the EIDL, less any advance received under an EIDL COVID-19.{{refn
An applicant applies for a PPP loan directly with an eligible private lender, such as a [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
column2: federally insured bank]], a [[Federal Credit Union Act
column7: Farm Credit System institution]], or a Small Business Administration-approved lender.{{refn
column15: title= The Lowdown on CARES Act Loans

column1: The Small Business Administration has a standard application form, although private lenders are allowed to use their own paper forms or electronic forms if they are substantially similar to the standard form. An applicant must attach documentation to support the amount of the loan applied for, such as payroll reports, payroll tax filings, [[1099-MISC
column2: Form 1099-MISC]], or a sole proprietor's income and expenses. If these records are unavailable, a lender may accept bank records if they sufficiently demonstrate the qualifying amount.{{refn
column3: name= interim}} Applicants must make certain assertions, including that \"current economic uncertainty makes this loan request necessary to support the ongoing operations of the applicant\".{{refn

column1: Applying for a PPP loan is free to the applicant.{{refn
column2: name= lowdown }} An applicant is not charged any application fees by either the private lender or the federal government. The Small Business Administration compensates lenders are compensated for processing PPP loans.{{refn
column3: name= interim}} [[Certified Public Accountant]]s and accounting firms who are not allowed to charge businesses to prepare their applications for PPP loans; instead, the lender compensates them directly.{{refn
column10: title= CPAs Providing Billable Advisory Services to Small Business May Not Want to Be an Agent
column12: publisher= Association of International Certified Professional Accountants }} }} Nevertheless, an accounting firm is allowed to charge a business for providing advice on deciding which loan program and tax relief program would be best for their business.{{refn

column1: Some lenders will only accept PPP applications from businesses that already have a depository account at the lender.{{refn
column7: title= PPP Loans: Lender List and Requirements

column1: Loan applications will only be accepted through June 30, 2020.{{refn
column8: title= FAQ: What firms need to know to apply for monetary aid

column1: Making a false statement to obtain a PPP loan is a crime subject to possible imprisonment, fines, or both.{{refn
column8: title= How To Avoid Going To Prison For Your Paycheck Protection Program Loan: Advice From Former Federal Prosecutors

column1: Applications for PPP loans will be accepted, approved, and disbursed in the order of [[first-come first-served]], until the entire $349{{nbsp}}billion appropriated by [[United States Congress
column10: title= The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act and You

column1: Loan payments are not required to be made for six months. The loan has a [[Maturity (finance)
column2: maturity]] of two years. Each PPP loan has an [[interest rate]] of 1 percent.{{refn
column9: title= Government Doubles Interest Rate on SBA Loans After Banks Complain

column2: guarantee]]d by the U.S. Small Business Administration.{{refn
column3: name= lowdown }} An applicant does not need to provide any [[collateral (finance)
column5: personal guarantee]]s in order to apply or be approved for a PPP loan.{{refn
column6: name= lowdown }} A PPP loan is a [[Nonrecourse debt
column7: non-recourse loan]], unless the loan proceeds are used for unallowable purposes.

column1: Payroll costs, including health insurance benefits and retirement benefits, are allowable, although the portion used for compensation is limited to $100,000 annualized per worker.{{refn
column9: title= Paycheck Protection Program Loans: Three Things The SBA And Banks Need To Agree On Now

column1: Up to 25 percent of the loan may be used for non-payroll costs.{{refn
column2: name= basics}} Allowable non-payroll costs include business payments of mortgage interest,{{efn
column3: Mortgage interest payments are allowable if the mortgage was obligated prior to February 15, 2020. Mortgage principal payments are not allowable.{{refn
column5: Interest payments are allowable if the loan was made prior to February 15, 2020. {{refn
column7: Rent payments are allowable if the lease was obligated prior to February 15, 2020.{{refn
column8: name= interim}} }} and utilities, such as electricity, gas, water, telephone, and internet.{{efn
column9: Utilities are allowable if service began prior to February 15, 2020.{{refn

column1: PPP loan proceeds may not be used to compensate independent contractors that provide services to the business, nor to compensate employees whose primary residence is not in the United States.{{refn
If the applicant operates internationally, the PPP loan proceeds must only be used for the benefit of its operations in the United States and its possessions.{{refn
column5: title= Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) 50 10, Subpart B, Chapter 2

column2: principal]] of a PPP loan will be either partially or fully forgiven under certain circumstances.{{refn
column9: title= Federal Reserve to backstop Paycheck Protection Program loans

column3: name= andyou}} Forgiveness is based on what the loan proceeds were spent on, to what extent the employer maintained or rehired its employees, and to what extent it maintained the wages of its employees.{{refn
column11: title= Small Businesses Have 'A Million Questions' About Paycheck Relief Loan as Applications Come Due

column1: # Take the business' average number of full-time equivalent (FTE) employees per month during the first eight weeks of the loan,{{efn
column2: Any former employee who is rehired by April 27, 2020, counts as being employed the entire eight weeks.}} and divide it by the average number of FTEs per month between February 15, 2019, and June 30, 2019.{{efn
column3: Alternatively, the business may choose to divide by the average number of FTEs per month between January 1, 2020, and February 29, 2020. A seasonal business divides by the average number of FTEs per month between February 15, 2019, and on June 30, 2019.}}

column1: # Multiply the above by the total amount incurred and spent on payroll costs, mortgage interest, rent, and utilities during the first eight weeks after receiving the PPP loan.

# If, during the eight weeks of the loan, the business reduced any employee's wages by more than 25% when compared to the previous calendar quarter, reduce the above amount by the amount of the reduction in wages.{{efn
column2: A business can disregard wage reductions to any employee who received wages exceeding $100,000 annualized during any single pay period in 2019. A business can also disregard wage reductions if it eliminated the wage reduction by June 30, 2020.}}{{refn
column9: title= How Much of Your PPP Will Be Forgiven?
